 Dear Sister Anne,   It is getting rather late Sabbath Evening but I believe I must write a letter to you tonight. Though perhaps I have done rather more should be done on the Sabbath of writing letters, and it now about ten oclock P.M.  The fact is I have been out of town for a couple of weeks. I that time the cold weather, frost and snow have departed, the Rivers cleared of ice, Navigation commenced, and the long hoped and expected latest of letters have arrived. I got in town last night, and among the rest found your excellent letter of Jan. 8. 1852. Some of the letters of course have been even longer on the way than was yours  Letter from Mother Lucy & Eliab of about the same date. I supposed likely they might have already got out of all patience in waiting for answers, and thought fit to write as soon as possible, especially as I am going out of town again early in the morning and shall be away from Post Office all the week.  You know I always write to Mother, Brothers & Sisters on the Sabbath; If I did not I fear I should not write quite so often. Today I have stretched the point a little and written also to my Dear Friend

Everett, who, you may remember was with me in New Hampshire, is now in New York, and very anxious to hear from me.  I do think however I have carried the Matter rather too far today, as I have already written, before commencing this fourteen closely written pages today!  You know though that we have no Afternoon service in the Churches here. Morning service at 11 and evening at 6. or 7. and the afternoons are very long.   I presume that before this time you have received other letters from me, as I have always written occasionally and rather frequently.   I suppose you hear more regularly and often perhaps from Bangor, than I do, so I need write none of my news to you.   Has Lucy written to you her account of Gen Hodgens visit there to see Mother, and how prettily Mother blushed when the old Gen. kissed her &c. She says Mother was going to box her ears for what she wrote to me. I do not know if she did or not.  I suppose they have written to you of the Nice beautiful New house that Samuel is having built for himself there in Bangor, all so fine.   Samuel will soon be pretty independently well off there in Bangor.  It seems he cleared $1400.00 by his Steam Mill operation last Season, in addition to his regular Monthly wages. That is doing pretty well, is it not?   Eliab I think is enjoying himself finely at school and I think it is being extremely good for him Had he better go back to Brown's? in the Spring

or go into business for himself?    I have not heard from Milo for some time, not since Mother left there I think, Although first little Charlie, and after Charles & Albina made a nice visit to Bangor. None of them write to me.  Charles though did write me a nice letter last Summer or Fall.  I wrote a letter to Almeda a week or two since, or not very long agon in Jan. at any rate.  Your remarks about Almeda are extremely just. I have been thinking about the same things. I am afraid I hay have been lacking somewhat in duty towards her. As for her children it belongs to Lucy and you to continue, and to Eliab and I to carry out whatever we can. Neither will be backward.  I would like to do something for Manie though he is not a boy that suits me exactly. Few boys do. But my business is rather a bad one. No boy or Young person without well formed and strongly fixed principles should be amongs Engineers  It would be or is a very bad school for youth, very much of temptation   In some respects it is a little akin to the Military profession, as Civil Engineering is in some respects more similar than one would imagine to it, brother or sister art of Military Engineering, the same all engrossing devotion to Mathematics & materiel, instead of - anything else.  Science everything, and everything else nothing.  Very high notions of honor, and very loose practice of morality.  But I remember me of the bird fouling its own nest!   It is a Noble profession, & not only that it is Mine

You speak of Winter here as necessarily very dreary  I have enjoyed it very much. My health has been excellent, and growing better & better. My business has been pleasant. I enjoy the riding very much and my horse never gets sloughed. By the way, I must tell you of my horse. I have bought a young horse that pleases me very much. Very high spirited,  but king, gentle, generous and courageous, and very playful. I love the fellow much. And I love to ride horseback.   As for staying here, I suppose I am pretty well established in it. I can doubtless do better here than elsewhere and can now have really a very comfortable place here. My headquarters and place of abode at Jonesboro, about the most pleasant place all things considered in the Southern part of the State.  I had the choice to go into the Northern or central part of the State, but preferred to stay here. I believe this is really the healthiest country and the country here is much better for my permanent interest as I think.  My pay is not bad at any rate I can lay up $1000.00 per annum clear of all expenses, which is not bad for a young man in any professury?  It is uncertain whether I could do as well any where else.  I do not fear the Ague. It is bad and fearful disease only because neglected. It is harmless and soon more? under control than almost anything else.   My this sheet is almost filled, and I shall get to bed before eleven.  I am inclined to think you had better quit teaching and go to Bangor & Milo and enjoy yourself.  What do I think of Kossuth. I think he is almost immeasuraly the greatest Man in the World  Eljen Kossuth!   Sincerely  I.S.

Jonesboro, Union Co. ILL
Thursday April 22. 1852

 Dear Sister Anne    Your excellent letter of April 3 was received yesterday, with much pleasure. Your plan of writing letters hastily and often is I think a very good one. It is one you know that I have always followed. I always scribble off a whole sheet perhaps of whatever comes upper most as fast as I can write, My letters of course are poor things, but they do not cost much either of time or effort. It is pleasant to hear frequently from friends, especially relatives even if they do not say anything very bright and when letters cost but three cents apeice it is hardly worth while to find fault with the quality. As far as your letters are concerned though I cannot see as the excellence of the style or matter is injured at all by the haste of writing.  I should think your French Correspondence with Eliab might be quite profitable as well as agreeable to both of you.   You are anxious about Eliab. I am and have been very much so. I hardly know what to do about it. It troubles me more than anything else I believe of late. I expect he has been quite sick at North Hampton

though he has not written very particularly about it. I hope that he is before this time at Bangor, though I have not heard from him for a week or two. Am quite anxious to do so.   About my being at Westfield to home to with you next July is extremely uncertain in spite of temptations you hold out before me. It is now quite possible that I shall go East next Month, sometime in May, probably before the Middle at least. If I have the chance then fairly, it would hardly do to wait and run the great risk of getting away later.  It would certainly be extremely pleasant if we could go home together.  It may be possible yet, and I will write as soon and as fast as I can tell about the Matter.   You give a fine description of Miss Woodbury  She must be quite an agreeable lady I think. How old is she? Is she Engaged? Is she really very homely?  You know my expressed determination if I do ever get East again not to come back here without bringing a wife, if I can find any New England girl who will come with me!   You spoke of Fun & humor as a recommendation. Certainly, one of the greatest possible for anyone, Especially if its exercise be mainly upon things not persons. It if fall into satire upon mankind or upon human nature it is dangerous and to be avoided. But there is perhaps no more beautiful expression of a really good heart.

than a sportive? looking in joyous good will upon the bright side of every thing.   My beautiful horse is dead. I really loved him, he loved me.  It pained me more than twice the worth of him to see him suffer. It would have affected any one to see him in his painful illness, strive so to lean his head against me, as if realising that I would help him if I could. Even when he could no longer stand he would reach his head round to get it to me.  I suppose he got poisoned. Night before last I stopped at Murphysboro, Jackson Co., where it is supposed that by some accident or carelessness, he got some seeds of the Castor Oil Plant, Castor beans they call them among his feed.  These beans are supposed extremely fatal to the horse, one of two only killing a horse at once. Yesterday morning he was as well as could be wished lively & merry as a bird, and this afternoon he died. He was a very promising young fellow, and perhaps worth a hundred dollars.   Well.  I am able to get another, but I would hardly see him suffer so for the worth of two such.   Why do you skip half of Macauley's England? Your Mr Johnson who has "done reading books" has done with one half of the enjoyment of life.  Those three states of Mankind, Physical, intellectual & Moral is perhaps just as fully true as that each individual must pass through such three states.  Birds are singing with you After 3. Here I believe there is nearly as good singing in the depths of Winter

as at any time of year.   This Spring is very unusually cold and backward, very much so; but I saw young birds, Bluebirds, full fledged days ago!   What do you think of Spiritual Rappings at Bangor? And of Dr Pond's sermon upon consulting familiar spirits?    Received letter from Lucy yesterday written March 22. Eliab not arrived at Bangor.   Lucy it seems has been writing successfully for the Mother's Magazine.   It is getting late.  10 1/2 P.M.   Write after & I will    Sincerely  I.S.

Du Quoin, Perry Co. Illinois
Sabbath, September 25th, 1853

 Dear Sister Anne    Your letter was received yesterday. We had been anxiously expecting it for some time, and wondering what startling developments it might contain; but must acknowledge that we were somewhat taken by surprise. Antoinette however stoutly maintains that she fully expected something of the kind. I cannot stop now for congratulations, felicitations, or condolences, but now more simply to direct you the way to get here. For come here you must at any rate: we cannot & will not have it any other way. And it is perfectly easy to get here nowadays, and with very little trouble. At Peru you are in the same state and only two or three hundred miles from here. In one year more we will have a Railway, the Main trunk of the Illinois Central direct from Peru or La Salle here. Now you will have to go round a little, by way of St Louis. You take tickets at La Salle to St Louis, by way of Alton. The route is partly the Ill. Central & Partly the Chicago & Missippi. There is now but 20 miles of Staging & in October likely the Cars will run all the way to Alton. From Alton a Steam Ferry Boat carries you a few miles to St Louis. From St Louis to Chester, Steam Boats are running all the time

The trip takes half a day, or a night; the boats mostly leave just as night. The Ohio River Packets are the best boats.   From Chester to Du Quoin is 40 miles across the Country. Horses & Carriages are always to be hired there to convey; or if you would let me know a day or two before hand, just what day you will be at Chester, I will be there with horses & Carriage to bring you out here, and will carry you back there. That will be the best way, make your arrangements before so as to know just what day, and let me know making allowance for slow & irregular Mails, and giving me a spare day or two for I may be away from home on the receipt of your letter.   I suppose you should allow two days from La Salle to Chester: that is if you wish to stop over in St Louis. If not, with good luck you would be only 24 hours. Can you not write to me before hand what day you will leave Peru or La Salle? If you direct Du Quoin Perry County ILL, it is more sure to come direct without detention       It is the best of all times of year to visit this Country; late enough to be most perfectly healthy - and yet before the time of bad weather & bad travelling.  
in different handwriting - Isaac's wife Antoinette (Nettie) adding a few lines

 Monday morn, Sept 26. My little humming bird being risen; washed & dressed and perched on a pillow in his carriage by my side, I proceed to add my voice in favor of your projected visit. How glad we shall be to see you. Do please come if it be possible. We are anxious not only to see Anne but her friend. Dear

Anne: what great and important tidings your letter brought to us! So soon to don the "Matrimonial Crown"  I am very glad that good friend of yours, Emily Coleman is with you. How much good she can do you  Lizzie Doe married too! The great school of Misses Rich & Doe!  Isaac exclaims.  Will you not long remember with pleasure this last year  so happily spent with dear relations. They will I know, for they often speak in letters to us of the Enjoyment your presence has afforded. Isaac is waiting to take this to the office; so I will not write more unto thee with ink and pen, but I trust - I shall shortly see thee, and we shall speak face to face   In much love -   Antoinette

Ducoign, Perry Co. ILL. Sept. 24. 1854

 Dear Sister Anne   Your letter of the 15th inst. to Charles was received last night. We were both very glad to hear from you. I had been a long time expecting a letter from you: and really ought to have written myself long before, whether I heard from you or not.   But really I have been very much pressed with business this Summer. I have written letters only in direct answer to those I have received; and have done little else except just as I was absolutely obliged to do it.  You know it has been exceptionally hot everywhere. here still More so. For three full months here there was no rain, and hardly a single day in the whole time when the thermometer was not above 90 [degrees] F. in the coolest places to be found. And at one time three weeks when it did not fall below 80 [degrees] F. at any time.  I could imagine nothing like the drouth except perhaps in Sahara, or perhaps on the Pampas of L.A.  The Atmosphere night as well as day seemed perfectly dry. For a whole month there was not a particle of dew even.  The drough has been very extensive and very bad all over the Country; but I have

but I have heard of no place where it has been quite as bad as in this immediate region.   But my health has been very good, and I have felt the heat much less than I did last year & year before when it was not nearly as excessive. I believe I have become thoroughly acclimated here. But my principal Assistant Mr Mitchell, has been sick this Summer - laid up for a whole month with Billious Fever. That of course very much added to  my labor & cares. And since Mr Mitchell's recovery, others of the subordinates have been sick a good deal, thus taking Mr Mitchell time to attend to details, and depriving me of much of his assistance.  William Crosley of Hampden Maine who you know came out here with me, and is now my  Mr. Mitchells Sender? in charge of the Track Laying has been unwell - has the ague so much he is worth but little.  There is a good deal of sickness everywhere this Season; much more than last. My own health though remains very good.   I do not know when I shall go East. It is very difficult for me to get away at all. It is hardly decided whether Antoinette will come out here again this Fall. Probably not however.  It is a sickly season, and hardly safe for her to come out till rather late - and then it will be but a short time before I shall get through here; and it is hard for her to travel so far with a child.

I did think to get through by the first of December; but may not before the first of January.  I have a good deal to do first.  If necessary I would have got away about October 1st; but as I could stay, more is put upon me, in finishing up, and getting regular trains in operation.  After I do get through here I expect a vacation. You have not heard of the great "something" that didn't quite "turn up" in my case. You did probably hear of the celebrated "Minnesota Land Bill". Congress passed an Act making a great grant of Land to a Co. to build a great Rail Road in Minnesota. Afterwards an acc't of some supposed fraud repealed the act. That act established a great R.R. Co. which would have gone on with the best prospects of any new R.R. project in the Co.  Well; the Engineering was offered to our Chief Roswell B. Mason. He could not of course leave the ILL. Central at present; but was to have a sort of honorary charge of the new project, putting on Engineers of his selection, and over looking the Surveys and Locations. - And - I.S. Metcalf of 2nd Div. I.C.R.R. (who is supposed to have appeared himself very well there) was to have had a highly honorable & responsible position upon the new Road in Minesota. {Please excuse this spot}  This would have been the height of good fortune: for in the present depression of the Rail Road interests generally such chances are likely for a while to be remarkably scarce. However the friends of the Minnesota & North Western R.R. Project say that it is certain to go eventually; and it is only to wait a year.

And after all it will not be extremely unpleasant after three or four years confinement here to have a summer for recreation & rest, instead of being obliged to harry away to a new Road this Fall. months before I could finish my business here with any satisfaction to myself, or my principals. I do dislike very much to leave any thing I undertake unfinished. I have begun, and carried on, this 52 miles of RailRoad - and I really like to finish it. 
and expect to get some credit for it.
By the way, it is whispered that I have for here the finest stone bridge (for a little one) in the Western States: Some say even more than that of it. I cost $15,000.00 and certain Judges of Masonry & Architecture have pronounced it worth $50,000.00!
Well I have filled this letter with "I".  Excuse it.
I am sorry to gear that your fruit is injured by the Drouth. Here the fruit is almost entirely destroyed. In very poor places is there any at all Eatable.
Our first rain here was last Tuesday 19th
Do you really expect Mother to come West this Fall? I do wish she would. Mother & Lucy write as if they would go to New Hampshire this Fall.
You have heard how badly Albina bears Charles' absence. I expect they blame me for keeping him. We will probably return soon. His health has been very good here. 
I hope you will write again soon & oftener

                                                                     Sincerely
                                                                                  Isaac

Windsor House, St Paul, Minnesota Territory
Sabbath P.M. July 8, 1855
Dear Sister Anne
They call this the North Western Metropolis, and I believe it is quite worth visiting. I have as yet seen nothing of the surrounding country, but have spent one day here: arrived here yesterday morning, and employed the day in looking about the town.  It does seem something like a Mushroom, or an exhalation that has sprung up over these bluffs in a night, and one almost feels almost anxious for the effects of a mornings sun upon it. Less than seven years ago this was all an untrodden Wilderness; Now a city of six or seven thousand inhabitants, and 15000 emigrants have arrived here already this spring. It is not altogether such an unsubstantial affair either. The really 'First Class Hotel where I am stopping cost $40.000.00 or $50.000.00. And there is another building this season  to cost $100.000.00.  There are two or three, perhaps more ten & twelve thousand dollar churches. I was a little surprised or amused at the sermon I heard this forenoon from Rev. E.D. Neil of the First Presbyterian Church. It was simply a Fourth of July Oration - a pretty good one for a Military celebration I should think. To be sure he took a text, but it was only to introduce his subject, and exactly that 'Righteousness Exalteth a Nation', but rather the glory of this nation in its rulers & founders especially Washington. Most of it in fact was simply a Eulogy of the Character of Washington  Very well in its way, but did not seem to me very much a sermon

There is no afternoon service here until 8 P.M. So I shall occupy part of the P.M. in writing Letters.
After I left you at Elyria, I stopped about two days at Chicago, and reached DuQuoin on Sat. Night. I staid thereabout nine days, leaving again last Monday night at 12 P.M. and on Wednesday night July 4th left Dunleith on the Minnesota Packet Galena. The river was rather cold, and we were delayed by fogs so as to be obliged to lay up nights, and did not arrive here until Saturday morning.
The Upper Mississippi! I cannot describe it. You must come up here some time to see it for yourselves. If there is any river scenery in the world to compare with it, it is somewhere that I have not seen. The beauty of the Hudson River Scenery! Why the Hudson can about as well compare with the Upper Mississippi as a Trout Brook with Niagara. There - I suppose I am wild - but I was really carried away with it - I did not expect any thing of the kind, and really could not make any comparisons. The River valley is from two to unclear miles wide, bordered by bluffs 200 to 400 feet high in every variety; some times bald perpendicular or overhanging walls of rock, like the Hudson river palisades; sometimes rocky walls, half concealed in trees & shrubbery; sometimes beautiful green grassy slopes to the very top: sometimes sprinkled with trees like orchards: sometimes part grassy slopes, and partly terraced

terraced walls of rock between, or long green slopes with turretts & castles of rock at their Summits. Frequently it would be a long grassy slope from the bottom, then midway a perpendicular wall of rock 20 or 50 or 100 ft. high, and above that another long grassy slope rounding away, perhaps sprinkled occasionally with trees, to a beautifully crowning summit, which you may imagine the edge of the mighty prairie whose only horizon is the sky above it. And then the variety of form and positions, as ravines & brooklets & streams and rivers come down through or among these magnificent barriers to mingle with the Old Father of Waters.  And then the valley below this 2 to 5 Miles of River is but little of it water. It is full of Islands, Islands of every shape; low grassy islands, with lagoons full of lillies in quiet beauty; Islands of bushes; & magnificently wooded Islands; high prairie Islands, or sprinkled with low trees like orchards - and all just as nature left it - . Then the river, in numerous & varied channells everywhere winding, gliding or hurrying among these islands. The course of the Steamboat would be, now, in a channel at one side right under a mighty perpendicular bluff of rock, the home of the Eagles; now winding for miles along the beautiful Islands; and anon on the other shore skirting that Magnificent slope, a very mountain of smooth grass.

Most of the 300 or 320 Miles between Dunleith & St Paul is as I have described.  Most is called Lake Pepin some 30 Miles long, is simply the 2 to 5 miles wide river without the islands, but bordered by the same glorious bluffs & prairies.
Well really after all I have tried considerable to describe the Upper Missippi (sic). At any rate you may be sure it is worth the seeing.
I can hardly tell how long I shall stay up here; probably two weeks or so. There is to be a great Indian Payment some 150 miles up the river this week or next which I want to attend. It is said to be quite an exhibition, then I want to visit both the St Croix valley where the Furbers live, and also the Minnesota River valley which I suspect is to be the great place  When I do return I shall probably go by way of Elyria 
Sincerely
Isaac S.

Bangor Sun. Sept. 8th 1839
Dear Sister
I expect that James F. Walker (my room mate, you know! will go to Boston before long, I gladly embrace the opportunity of writing of few lines to you, that you may know that I am again digging at the Greek and Latin &c.
I have been home and spent five weeks; got back last Monday, Sept. 2. I had an excellent Visit; was at home just about in haying time. The hay is very good this year, got in 36 loads before I left and had all the bank and the seed hay, (4 acres) to cut then. Charles has got a Cradle and cradles his grain this year; had cut 2 1/2 acres of Wheat and one of Oats before I left. The wheat is not very good this year I believe. The folks were all in very good health  Joseph came and brought me down with the horse and waggon; we got down here about 3 P.M. and Joseph went back as far as Mower's tavern the same night.
I suppose that you have heard that got home safe and well August 23d, but she left my books behind her and I want them right off, this week. Ann, I believe, wrote to James to send them by the steamboat, and I can get them at the steamboat office
I do not see as I can find any thing to write you to fill out my letter hardly; every thing gets along pretty much as it used to at home and I am sure, there is nothing here to write about, it is all the same dull,

unenvied routine of Studies and Chores, day after day and week after week till you are tired of it.

 I have more time to study out of School hours now than I shall have by and by I expect rather. when time comes to dig garden souce? etc. cetera. I now milk the Cow, feed and turn her out, feed the pigs, make the fires, dig vegetables to eat etc. besides many little chores. I shall have to saw wood, when it comes winter, if I stay here.
 While I was to home once a Fox, or Muskrat, and a wild duck, but the Fox died and we let the duck go so that only the mucky remains crossed out it is a real pet. I stay at home and write this letter today, because my coat is not done so that I can go to church, decently.
Old Mrs. Harlow, Grandmam, is now in her 80th year and has within a few weeks made up entirely a pair of shirts. herself, for J.B. Walker. Is not that a considerable of a story to tell of an Octogenarian?
  Wed. Sept. 18th
    I wrote the preceeding some time since, expecting to send it by I.T. Walker, but he afterwards concluded not to track that way so I laid it in my trunk, but to day, Mr. N. Hatch, who has been to Milo; brought me some letters from Ann etc. to send to Boston. I thought I would send this as it would be easier than to write a new one! I shall sent it with the other if I have a chance. I recieved the bundle of books, letters etc. from Boston, Mon. 16th and sent part of it to Milo the same night, but it had not been received when Mr. Hatch left there. it is rather a pity that they had not. The books come very opportunely, and were much needed

I expect that you will find all the news from Milo in the other letters; however, the boys have got their little butter way again! Why did you not write to me by the bundle? You orturn. In Mr. Burke's letter, he said I must write an answer to it, how can I? I cant no hom, dont know how no hour  I am getting along pretty well in my Latin and Greek; just beginning to read in Greek. Most, that is more than half through Virgil.  Compositions bother me greatly as yet, I have spoken to day, cant make out much, at that, neither. My coat is being made at Mr. Fox, tailor, here. will be done sometime this week. I am rather sorry, that so costly a one was got for me. I dont approve of fine and expensive dressments. I dont at all suppose that this letter is worth sending, but if I can send it as well as not I will.
Mr. Hatch went to Milo the 10th and did not get back till to day was there a week, quite a visit, it is vacation the seminary

Goffstown Jan. 7 1850
                                                                        Brother Samuel
                      I enclose to you a letter to my Mother, who is probably at your house before this time. At least she wrote of going there last week.
   What do you think of Howell Colb as Speaker of the House? Do you, like some in these parts, try to throw the blame upon the 'FreeSoilers'  instead of where it rightly & really belongs, upon the 'Whig Party"? However isn't that same Whig Party in rather 'bad sledding' this Winter? What can they do?
 I look with the most hope for this Winter to old Benton. He is now the most prominent man in the country. He unites great powers of mind with a greater portion of Common Sense than most men. He takes wider views of things than most politicians
  That Senate Chamber is to be a mighty Battle Field this Winter; a glorious one too I hope, if Henry Clay does not creep on with some miserable paltry "compromise" or other. It does seem as if Clay were old enough & should be wise enough, to look farther ahead than one session of Congress. It is strange that with his splendid abilities, he can never comprehend that another generation is to succeed this. How different from Benton, or Webster, if Webster only had moral courage enough to be governed by his own foresight.
 But I am afraid this kind of politics will not interest you.
                                                 Write to me.
                                                            I.S.M.

Isaac March 3d                                         Goffstown N.H. March 3, 1850
Dear Sister Lucy, I have not heard one word from any of you since I left Bangor, and that seems a great while agone, Feb.10. I wrote to Charles & Eliab from Portland, and again to Joseph or some of you after I got here, about 15th perhaps After that I went around into Mass. To Grouts 19. 20th to Greenfield where are established some of my old folks. Mr. A. R. Field & wife, My Rufus, Mr. Cropsman & wife, in fact our whole party at Northfield. I spent a day or more there very pleasantly. Mr. Cropman got up an evenings refreshment of all manner of fruits etc. & a grand time. Mr. Field, who you must know is a very saving man, insisted upon paying my expenses, and hoped I would give him the privelege of so doing frequently.

21st I went to Northfield, called at Parsons', Dickinson's, whose oldest boy Williams you know has been very sick for a year nearly. Feversore etc. also at Rev. Mr. Jones, Mr Duttons etc.
 22d With Coz Joseph & wife etc who came up from Grouts, Hired horses & went out to Warwick. w. Uncle Joseph's found that Eve. one of the celebrated Unitarian "Braiding Parties" nearly a hundred folks, every room full braiding Palm leaf. I had no idea there were so many folks in Warwick. Some of them rather awkward & slow of life. { You know it takes a Warwick folks from 2 to 10 years to live one year's life usually;} but they are really pretty good sort of folks, and appeared to enjoy themselves very well.

Feb. 25. We made quite a day of it. In the morning rode up to Aunt Conant after her, but she was Baking and would not come till After Noon. So we went over to Uncle Williams! Staid there to Dinner. Then took Lucy & went back to Uncle Joseph's Aunt Conant there & a nice time.  Aunt C is really a very superior woman, considering her circumstances & life. It must be a strong mind even to not become imbecile in such a life as theirs. We got a big horse sled, & slided down hill on the crust, grand, Joseph, Jane, Maria, Lucy & I. We did try so hard to get all those old folks to sliding. I would have given 1000 myself to have got Uncle S Aunt C upon that sled. I would have warranted them five years younger. They did all come out and look at us; and I know that Uncle Ban has not felt so well for years as he did that day. But Uncle Joseph was the only one we could get on to the sled; He became about as young as any of us.

At Night, we went over to Edward Mayo's, and made a call There were some pretty smart girls there, Maria & Anne Mayo quite well educated etc. I made their acquaintance at "Braiding Meeting." Then back, Uncle Joseph, then I carried Lucy W. home & stopped there. I never got acquainted with Lucy William's before. She is certainly a very fine girl. She hasn't her equal in those parts I know. That Baldwin did not begin to be worthy of her.  They say it was probably at the time you were there Summer before last that they separated; and nobody there ever suspected it perhaps for six months! she has never even mentioned his name.  If she were not my Cousin & a Unitarian I declared I do not know but I should like Lucy Williams! She cannot enjoy herself

very well there I do believe, wants to go away & teach but her father is not willing. I do believe she & Maria Stevens will go down East this Summer. I should not wonder you had a lot of Mass. folks to expect. Uncle & Cos. Jos. Uncle Jacob etc. possibles.  
Mon. 25th. Joseph carried Aunt Esther home with him. Uncle Jos. went to Boston and I to Royalston. Uncle Jacob same as Ever: done all his work himself and it is near 150.00 worth of timber, Chair stuff. Any hard work stick 4 in. though is worth 3.00 per cord there you know. Samuel gon away. Aunt rheumatis one of her daughter there. Josiah teaching school in Templeton. He broke a boy's leg in school this winter by accident, sued for 1000.00 damages.

  Called at Mr. Perkins, Mrs. P. very sorry that her daughters were not at home! Mr. P is a shrewd speculator, sending lumber to California etc. smart business man has not been to Church for a Year!  Obadish Goddard is getting rich, fast. He buys cattle in Feb & March, 20 or 30 sells Fat Cattle in summ

26th P.M. next back down to Grouts. Night went to Boston in Cattle Train with Joseph. Got there morning early. Staid there till left corner of letter missing 
March 1st. Free Soil Convention  etc. Came up here yesterday.

I did think of getting home last week, but concluded ill things considering to come up this way, and go and attend a great N.H. Central RailRoad Meeting this week at Newport. By the way, I met Mr. S.R. Price our N.H. C. "Agent" in Boston, who desired with much earnestness that I should not engage any where else, said there was prospect Mr. Chase might leave and they would want me immediately!  crossed out  which put me in mind of Mr. Field's asking me next year when I had charge of the N.H.C.R.R. to give him a Division under me, if he wanted!!
But that is all folly Mr. Chase will stay. Mr. C. & Mr. P quarrelled, but I guess it is settled.  If I can keep on in good terms with both & all parties, I will do well. I am so at present.  Mr. Chase wants me sure, if he goes on, & the Agent & Directors would offer me any thing. Still I may fall through between both, if the Road does not go one.  

 I bought some books in Boston; among the rest, Cheever's Lectures on Pilgrim's Progress, which Joseph wanted to read. I bought a few books at Auction. the temptation was too great, to have money in my pocket and see books sold cheap as that etc. I do want to hear from you all and Joseph especially. I think it too great thing to not turn? up at Newport I shall get home next week

bottom part of the this letter is from two pages previous

These Boys are more full of excellencies than an egg is full of Meat - as you will readyly perceive by some of thier Communications I very much need you here to help me take care of 'em.
 I'm going to send your old Carpet bag by Mr. Welch it contains treasures untold - or to come a little nearer  the truth I couldn't find any thing that was hardly worth sending but did "what I could".
  Joseph Seems to be as well as he has been as far I as I can see he does not walk at all now except a step or two when he goes to bed (it has been very difficult hard for him you know for a long time) think it best perhaps to try it while Isaac is here
 Almeda is here - came down herself notwithstanding it is excessively muddy she has not been here before this long time - there are great banks of snow here & there by the side of the fences etc. and the road is very bad indeed
 Sophia Thomson had her Breast taken off - Almeda was there  she bore the operation better than was expected I have not heard from her since
 If I send you some money for it you will please get some Cord & tassels for window Curtains and Almeda wants tassels and some black worsted. I cant think of any thing that is necessary but say now only do come home soon as you can conveniently

I want a catcechism for Lizzie go to Eliab for funds for it for full trimming I send you Montgomery Work.
Take of my money at Eliab's to get Mothers cords & tassels Almeda

Mother has been writing to Lucy, but on inquiring for her letter to write a few words, it turns out to be only certain homeopathic scraps of paper she has written on.
Well, I fear that this part of the World is to suffer great loss. Having been appointed Chief Engineer of the N.H. Central R.R. I may feel myself obliged to tear myself away.
We want Samuel & Eliab to discover and let us know whether Alfred Holman is at work in the Steam Mill, what he is doing, and whether he could for any reasonable compensation be procured to come and take care of Joseph or carry on Charles' farm and let him do it.

This should be known & decided upon immediately.
I trust Lucy that you are already a good deal better than when you were here do be careful of your self - dont let it wear upon you if the girls are trouble some remember they are but children - Lucy, & mind seems all taken up with Mr. Temple - tis natural he has taken great interest to in her Spiritual welfare - he really seems to be a very Spiritual minded devoted Man he feels a great anxiety for John Furber it behooves you & Samuel to talk with him - find out his state of Mind encourage him and lead him on there were 10 person Stopt at the enquiry meeting last Sabbath

 Now as Isaac is going away we will be more anxious than ever that you come home and stay awhile say when raspberries are ripe - how lonesome and sad one shall be without Isaac- C. & A. have pretty concluded they shall not go to  B to Bangor this summer before haying.

Thank you very much Dear Daut. for your good long letter ye are a nice good Gal for it, & for remembering the birth days & for many other things - Did n't it hurt you awfully to have your teeth fill'd and the decayed roots extracted I suppose that was the worst. It made me feel almost sick thinking of it. The fear of the Dentist having a poor job of it for himself did n't worry me at all I think they make money enough in their business generally. O Dr. Webster - What are the highest attainments without religious principle - How strange it is that he could command himself so as to appear just as usual all that week before his Arrest. It was n't convenient to except your invitation - their Husbands - did n't know that Margaret & Sarah had any hope they are good ones. I want to see your Pictures they were very cheap if they were such as are worth having at all. I think your dresses very pretty.

 Almeda is about making hers - I have done nothing about to mine I shall need it soon - but it is most to pretty to near common as I shall have to - I dont let Albina have the veil. How pleasant & good it is to have Isaac here with Josie his being out of business which to some might seem unfortunate seems to me a kind of providence. How unlikely it is that they'll ever have such a time again J. does not walk any to speak of  now I dont know but he would some if Isaac were not here he has written to Dr. Paine frequently is taking his medicine he has written to Dr. Munde likewise. He does not take his Bath except once a week or so.

Joseph had a beautiful Mark from H.A. Moore a day or two since. I believe Joseph wrote to Dr. Tappan and to Dr. Shepherd in behalf of us poor Milo sinners he has not heard from Dr/ S. but Dr. T. wrote him a letter Stating that he had written to Rev. Wooster Parker on the Subject crossed out & He concur'd the afternoon that there ought to be a Missionary sent here that He thinks very favorably of a supply being granted. But deems it highly important that it should be the right Man - says we hope to obtain for you during the approaching Vacation in the Seminary in Bangor an acceptable faifhful young man belonging to the present Senior Class. Is n't it lamentable that a universalist once in 4 or 8 weeks is all the preaching we have in town - we have a society Meeting at the Corner of 15 or 20 persons Isaac reads. Mr. Bumps talks & sings prayer meeting at Almeda's 10 or 15 generally including the family Mr. Richer seems quite engag'd & consistent his prayers & exortations Short but very good & appropriate - pray for us little reason for expecting any right State of feeling at present you that have the blessed priveleges of hearing Dr. Shepherd big Sermons must be rising on the scale of being far above us poor wretches here i.e. if you are faithful to yourselves we seem to be hermetically Seal'd in thick darkness

 If Sam'l Business should be principally in Bangor would not you find it expedient to move there.

[upside down and left-hand side] I have just been reading JR's Essay or lecture on health. Doubtless it contain some truth at any rate you'd think so should you see how he does "practice upon the precepts inculcated" you certainly would give him credit for being sincere. If I had room I would introduce a commentary upon this passage. You perceive its obscurity. I would simply throw out a suggestion that Dreams are sometimes interpreted by contraries.

You ought to have gone to the Dentist sooner Lucy. I think I have told you so before. It costs more and is less efficacious beside after the teeth have become so much decayed. I had mine filled three or four holes, two or three years since by a Dentist of Reputation in Brattleboro for $.50 per cavity. So I  should think you paid a pretty good price.
Another thing now I think of it, I want to give you a lecture upon the Subject of health, as I have lately to Eliab. There is perhaps no need of enlarging upon the excellence of the blessing, or the importance of preserving it generally; still you & Eliab do need warnings. With you as well as with Joseph there is a great fundamental defect of character : the great primary preservation principle of Laziness. is almost entirely wanting. With Josepha hundred thousand dollars would not be a fair equivalent for the injury that defect has caused him. We cannot tell the extent of the injury already caused to Eliab; perhaps twenty years of life. You all started in life with a wrong principle, a wicked sinful principle: viz. that your own personal ease comfort & convenience, were of no sort of importance or at least secondary: instead of being as in truth the great principal all important thing. "Self preservation is the first law of Nature." A benevolent God has implanted most minds sufficient Laziness & selfishness to secure this. In some few cases, either as a furnishment for sins of some preceding generations or to give opportunity of trial for a new triumph of Right reason over difficulties, He has withheld the Boon. It is your imperative moral duty to consider yourself of more value than many sparrows; your own ease comfort & feelings more importance than any else whatever. } I guess I will omit the remainder of this occasion until some future opportunity.
 Mother ordains that you come up here again as soon as possible.
How long I remain is uncertain; am liable to go about every other day. Think some of going Down East. St. Andrews & Quebec R.R. Expect to hear from there very Soon. Did Mother write that I am lazy? I have cleansed the Augean Stables, and performed various other wonders upon the Old Book Case & Newspaper Shelves;  have burned up with fire, and sold for paper rags 100 cords old worthless books and papers; and should like to do the same by double quantity of old clothes etc. If I find some opportunity when Mother was out of the house. There no telling how I find the Way through 'em to get up stairs to bed a nights.

Manchester R.R. Nov. 10. 1850

Dear Sister Lucy

 I hope you have got pretty well by this time; and intend to come and see for myself pretty soon, perhaps before the week is out; perhaps not. 
 You can not tell how frightened I was when I first heard that you were very sick. Samuel's letter did not reach me for a long time, perhaps till you were most well, or nicely getting well. It went first up to Bradford, then remailed from there to Oil Mill Village; and at last after a day or tow found its way down here. I kept thinking that perhaps that you were worse and I did not hear of it for so long; and troubling myself among other things because I had not written as soon as I came down here to let all the folks know where I was.
 And now, though, I have heard once or twice since then that you were getting better nicely, yet I am quite anxious to hear again how you get along. Mother it seems has gone home to Milo, and Almeda come down to stay with you. Anne, I believe I understood from the latest letter had gone to Milo, or was going. I really want to see her; and mean to before long.
 Your little one is dead. I suppose it was hard parting with it, even though you had hardly time to begin to love it : yet it always seems to me it is hardly right to mourn in such a case, the death of an infant. In one sense, is not the soul of that child a fortunate one? It has received of God

the glorious gift of life - life & immortality; and then in the enjoyment of that Godlike gift, is released at once from all life's evils & uncertainties, from sin & sorrow, from trial & probation. One should rather rejoice in having given birth to an immortal soul, a soul saved by Christ, and without the sin & evil of life, and the uncertainty of probation,: a soul awaiting for you in a better and happier world than this: "one more added to the attractions of heaven" Is it not so?

  Again may not the world be better even for that Child's short life, if it warms & purifies one other heart giving it one other silver tie to the better world; and this that Child's short thread of life better accomplish life's great end, than many a threescore years & ten.
    I am almost beginning to like Manchester. I have always disliked it before you know. One reason may be I have always before been obliged to stop at the Public houses, and I do not like them very well. Now I board at a private boarding house which I like much better. The "folks" are three old Maiden Sisters, one a Congregationalist, one Episcopalian, one Methodist, and all very good sort of people. F'or other boarders beside Everett & Myself are a N.H. Central R.R. Office Clerk, a very gentlemanly sort of a man with his wife & children, the Dry Goods Clerk, and three Milliner girls, very respectable people too, and two at least of then, head Milliners, in different shops.
On the whole, I like bothe the people and the folks very well, and much prefer it to the Hotel, beside being cheaper; which is great point to Everett especially.

This Evening I dropped into the Methodist Church. The fact is I do really like the Methodists, on some accounts. To tell the plain truth about it, I am almost inclined to think sometimes that I ought to have been a Methodist Perhaps it would have made a better man of me and I really believe I should have been valuable as a Methodist. I should have enjoyed their fervor and enthusiasm, and perhaps partaken more of it, and yet, being quicker to feel & think, than to express feelings & thoughts, might have been a pretty good balance to some of the rest.

   Samuel, do you want to borrow some more money? I ought to have received a hundred or two of the N.H.C. before this time, probably shall soon at any rate, and could lend it to you if you want it. Moreover three hundred and fifty or more dollars of my last year's account, which I left on interest will be due the first of January.
 There was one time when I almost wished I had the money it on my hand instead of the Note. Though I suppose any thing against any Corporation is perfectly safe in N.H.. All the Stock holders private property being holden. In fact too, Much as they have been pressed for Money the N.H. Central has never had a Note protested.

Milo, Maine, Sat. May 15. 1850

Dear Sister Lucy

    We have very much expected you up here this week, and have concluded that we were disappointed only on account of the extreme Rain of yesterday
 By the way this renewed rain is very bad for brother Charles and other farmers in this region. { Very Wet River up on the Intervale every few days} Charles has neither planted or sowed yet. His ground was just getting dry, and, he had got about ready to plant, when comes this great rain of Thurs. night, Friday entire, and this morning continued, and delays indefinitely.
  Well - but, I am writing this in supposing that as you are not up this week, you will be next, and I want you to bring up some things I have in your house.  It appears quite probable that I may continue to remain here as of heretofore - If it were not for Joseph's case, I should now, or rather long since, not be here.  As it is, I hardly feel justified in leaving him in his present state, except on some very urgent call and plain indication. I am able to remain here this summer. Eliab or I, - I judge, must. You hardly realise perhaps how much he has failed since you saw him. He cannot now move his foot or turn in bed, without help etc.
  All things considered, I have concluded to remain here until more especially obliged to leave. I somewhat wish my Trunk was here, but perhaps it is only best to have some things put in my valise and brought up. I want especially a pair of Shoes which are there. Also "Gray's" and "Bigelow" Botanys.

Perhaps also papers, writings and other books from my trunk Bring up any thing you think I may want, that there is chance to bring, especially a think Neck cloth, perhaps, Linen or anything else. If I do stay here I am good mind to have my Trunk sent up, but no Matter.

  Joseph his Bran Meal and Crush Wheat are about gone, and I suspect he expects to receive renewed portions thereof from Bangor, through you folks.
    This writers name is I.S.

Parker's Goffstown N.H. Oct. 28. 1850

Dear Sister Lucy

  It seems a good while since I have written to you, or heard at all from you. Whether the fault be mine, I can hardly say either. I have usually forgotten whether I wrote last or not. I did some think I might get Down East before long; but cannot now tell how it may be. I have before written to the rest of the folks if I have not to you, about our troubles in the N.H. Central R.R. this Fall - a quarrell with another corporation about the "right of way." A trouble involving the very existence of the Upper End - my end - of the Road - from Bradford to Claremont.  It became so serious that the Board of Directors notified me to discharge my men mostly & make as little expense as possible until the matter was decided.
  The "Hearing" before the N.H. Board of R.R. Commissioners, who were to decide the question, was held at Concord N.H. last week commencing on Tuesday. I was present as Engineer of the N.H. Central, for whom appeared as Counsel.  Josiah Quincy Jr. about the greatest R.R. Authority in N.E. assisted by other Surveyors etc. of less note. The Opposite side was managed by the celebrated Gen. Frank Pierce the hero of the Mexican War, and considered the most effective Reader that N.H. can furnish. On the whole it was quite an occasion.

After all the matter was not finally settled, but a full decision was deferred until Nov. 13th.

  The matter is however most like to go against our side. The "influence" whatever it may be called, which rules the State of N.H. {it is a curious state.} is "located" at Concord, goes by the name of the "Concord Clique", This influence is strongly enlisted against the N.H. Central R.R. with which I am connected, and in favor of the "Concord & Claremont" R.R. which consequently is like to prevail in spite of what is apparently rather a clear case.
   So - in view of circumstances- we have suspended operations in the field, dismissed all the Men except Self & Everett, and returned to quarters here, to finish up some Office Work. and - perhaps - shall get through in a few weeks.
  Alfred L.H. was paid off in full last Friday. I suppose that he was going right home. But I guess he does not like the idea of going back and going into the Woods to work, and finally concludes that if he can get employment he will stay in the vicinity.
  So I have him a recommendation to the Track Layer,  and I think likely he will get employment there, or on the Gravel Train, or something on the Road.
  I spent most of last week at Concord, and a beautiful place it is too Met there a College friend M. Goodwin, Principal of Concord High School- & assistants.
  Saturday, how it did rain. I was at Bradford. I could not go as I would for rain. I finally got

to Manchester by the Evening Train, and spent the Sabbath there. I never liked Manchester very well, and really much as I have been there, never spent a Sabbath there before. I was however better pleased there yesterday. Rev. Dr. Wallace, of the First Cong. Church I liked very much. He is really a large man - put me in mind once or twice, especially in the evening, when I heard him lecture on Temperance, of Wendell Phillips. Did you ever see or hear Wendell Phillips? Wendell Phillips is among the most eloquent men in this or any country - would be so considered of all men if it were not for the extremity of some of his opinions.

  How long I shall stay here, or what I shall so is extremely uncertain.
  I shall be Down East as soon as possible. At any rate I want you to write to me direct Manchester N.H.
  Samuel, among the troubles on the N.H. Central, Money is still scarce. I have not yet succeeded in getting enough to pay off all the men I have discharged. I do just get enough for myself to pay my expenses as I go along from week to week and those are considerable some of the time. Board $1.00 per day, to say nothing of "Brandy Segars"! But - money is promised me in a few days. If I get a supply, I will try to send you another hundred, if you want it, pretty soon. Perhaps I may be down there myself in a week or two.
                                                           Yours Affectionately
                                                                         I.S.M.

Isaac Oct 28

   Nov. 4 M Manchester N.H.
  Samuel I have just received your letter which went first to Bradford the Oil Mill Village. Is Lucy getting better? Oh! how I want to hear again. Do write immediately. I fear you have written & the letter gone again to Bradford, & Pil Mill. Why did I not send this letter last week? I deferred thinking every day, I would be able to get the money to send you some. Do write direct Manchester N.H.
 Mail time immediately   I.S.

I am very closely confined here, making out Estimates etc. before Commissioners Meeting Nov. 13 Work at Manchester instead of Parkers.
Do write immediately

Newbury, N.H. Sept. 15, 1850

Dear Sister Lucy

Your nice kind letter was duly received last night, and at the same time a long one from Mother & Joseph. Of course you can imagine that I had a treat, one which finely rested me after my weeks' work. 

I had a letter from Anne too last week; a nice one, though written about a month before, going first to Goffstown, then to Newport, and finally here. I have today written a letter to Anne, and one to Mother & Joseph; besides going out to Newport, eight or ten miles, to Church.
It is now quiet Sabbath Evening; and here we sit thinking of those far away. At Mt table, Self, Edward Everett, & Alfred each busily writing letters. I have got a grand good party. I think by far the best I ever knew. Only eight of us now. I.S. M Edward Everett, S.C.L. Burnham, Abram Mitchell, George W. Mitchell, Alfred L. Holman, Gilman W. Johnson, and John Flaherty. Alfred is an excellent fellow; influence always on the right side I think. He says he wull give $50.00 towards it himself if they will build a Meeting house in Milo.

 I heard a grand preacher at Newport today. Old Mr. Hood is away on a Journey and a Young Man from Cornish preached for him, the smartest young man I have heard this great while. I do not know where a really great man I think; and there are few such nowadays. Wellman is his name
 I was very much pleased with him. Even Alf. said he would not have missed hearing him for a V.

I am really glad that you could go to Milo, and stop a little while. It must have done Joseph good, besides being very pleasant for all the rest of you.

 I wish you could stay there a month or two.

So your Herbarium is fairly fixed up. I am right glad to hear it. You say Joseph is weaker than in June but does not lie down near as much. What does that mean? It cannot be that having no one there to take care of him all the time, he does not lie down or change his position as often as he otherwise would on account of giving less trouble to Charles. If that is the reason or if that has any thing at all to do with it, it is certainly not right - not by any means; and must be seen to immediately, Do write to me about it. And write to Mother & Joseph & Charles. All ought to know better. Joseph could not do so.
I do believe he is better, even if he does lose strength in his limbs. He must be better than in May and June or it would be impossible.

 You must be very careful of your health - more so, far more so, you ought to be than you are. It is a great entirety to kill one's self, and with all the good advice that I have given you, you certainly cannot pretend to have the excuse that you do it unknowingly. What do you have Charles Harlow there for? Is there nothing to prevent it? You ought not to.--------

David Copperfield you shall have - sometime.

 I am glad Mr. Wilson goes to Milo instead of Mr. Temple. Are you folks changing your opinion of E. B. Webb already?

Samuel, I wrote to Eliab about sending some money last week or the week before. I did not get it myself till Friday. And then it was all in small bills. Most convenient to be sure for two or three hundred dollars that I had to pay out here $100.00 I sent to Manchester Saturday to get a Cheque or large Bill for the small ones and will send on to you in some form tomorrow or next day probably.  When I shall have more I hardly know; ought to have early in October. Will take pleasure in sending to you whatever or whenever I have ' any thing crev?! occasionally when or if you want.
  I am in the way of spending considerable money for the Corporation nowadays, and they may think that they happen to be short that if they do not shell over quite enough for my own pay too; that I can get along.
  You have made quite extensive repairs upon the Senator. have you not? Isn't it rather risky,  such old craft as that?
                                                                          Tues. Morn.
                                                     Enclosed you will find Draft from Manchester Bank on Trader's Bank Boston for one hundred dollars, payable to my order I endorsed to you, which I obtained yesterday.
                                                                  I.S. Metcalf

Sunpee N.H. Aug. 8 1850

Dearest Sister

  Your letter of the Eighth instant was duly received sometime not long since.

I hope to receive another early as possible, I hereby attempt to write again myself upon the very first Sabbath. Sunday being the only time upon which I can find any time or opportunity to write letter.
You see I made a good beginning with that blot!
Last Sabbath I wrote to Anne. Today I have already written a long letter to Joseph and Mother. Last Sabbath was I believe the only one since I commenced here on which I have not written to Joseph. So you see I intend to keep up my reputation as a faithful letter writer, if I do have less time and circumstance than the rest of you to do it.

 Our folks at Milo are really to blame in that regard I think. Joseph to be sure cannot write himself now, but there are enough others to write for him. It is strange that they had not written to you better than you say. Mother & Joseph have written to me a few times, one letter I received last week. Joseph insists that he is no better, in spite of Alfred's very direct Affirmation.  I do hope that he is almost imperceptibly recovering.
 Alfred I suppose you want to hear of. He is doing finely and I believe likes first rate. His low spirits did not last long after he begun to get acquainted with our fellows. I guess he enjoys himself finely and he bids fair to make a very valuable man for me, when he gets fairly initiated and has learned more perfectly a variety of things.

I am very glad to hear of the restablishment of your health. You must be careful not to permit your work, or taking care of "Our husband", or the trials of patience of those girls, or company or any thing else, wear you out and make you sick again. To take care of health is about the first of duties.
 But I will not tier you with any more homilies upon this topic. If it were thought necessary, I should rather prescribe some of the old ones!
 The best we perhaps would be to send back to you some you have given me - even one in your last letter.
 Why do the Third Parish Church, Centre Church, do you call it, Why do they leave the Hall they have occupied. Why does Hannah Moore to the West teaching? Did I not understand that she was - of property?
                         Has Samuel more of business and care at the Mill than he has had heretofore? It must be more convenient for him to live so near.
                   Is Eliab full of business now a days?

That Daguereotype of yours, you know is my property, and to be kept for me. I left it as I did many other things I wanted. I did mean to keep that & Joseph's with me all the time. But now I am not located any where in particular, and have nothing with me. 
If I ever live long enough to have a home or even a place of my own, I shall begin to gather my possessions together. If I had any place for them I think I might perhaps find I had quite a property of trumpery of one kind and another. I declare I am almost disposed to get me some little brown wife sometime and try it. Much obliged for your catalogue of my books at yr. place.

"Elements of Law" I guess belongs to Joseph. Smellie I wish you would send to Joseph when you have opportunity. He wants to read it.

Old Joliffe I will give to you or any body that wants. Hactimus I thought I had given to you long ago when I first brought or carried home.
Evangeline also  I thought was yours but if you do not claim that I will

acknowledge it as mine again, or give you an Equivalent sometime, if I ever happen to
Dysentery and all that sort of Bowel disorders, how prevalent they are getting to be in these times. All the Old fashioned terrible diseases are going out of fashion before them. Almost every body nowadats is attacked with something of the kind upon any change of life.
Hardly any one of my party except myself has escaped more or less of sickness from such attacks.
Any change of boarding place will frequently bring it on. For my part I eat everything  with great appetite and much supply of health & strength.
Fruit of all kinds is extremely abundant this year. 

 I judge from your remarks upon Gov. Briggs and Prof. Webster that you are Anti Cap. Punishment.  But to me you come to the wrong place for sympathy. Did you not know that I am a determined advocate of Cap. Punishment for Murder. I believe in it religiously I do the Bible. It is part of my creed. Those opposed to it are at least in bad company. Prof. Upham is the only opponent I know with whom I should like to be associated. I am too proud to join the Universalists & other so called "Liberals" of the nowadays who make up the party. Not that I took my side on those ground. I think, that it was upon a thorough & candid examination of the whole case.
    Well I have made out quite a letter, more than I expected and very badly blotted. You must write to me soon and frequently.

This day I did not go to Newport to Church, but staid here to a Free Will Bap. two or three ignorant Elders in the pulpit. One very Old man I liked much though.

                                         Well it is getting late
                                                                         Good bye Affectionately

Do write & tell Eliab & Samuel to write                                                            I.S.

Newbury N.H.  July 29. 1850

Dear Sister Lucy

                           Here it is you see a fortnight since I left Home, and I have not heard a word from any body: Only a fortnight  - but it seems an age to me.
  It is a very warm evening, after an immense great Shower since Sunset. Ut is close cloudy and there seems hardly air enough here under the big Mountains, for us all to breathe here. It has been decided not to do much work this evening on account of the state of the weather and the prospect of saving time tomorrow.
 So as it is too warm to sleep. I am beginning to write but with three or four of my boys laughing and telling Old College Stories etc. in the room, and occasionally appealing to "Metcalf" for advice or opinion.
 Therefore - do not be surprised at most any kind of a letter from me. And moreover if this same should not happen to finished at this sitting, I may not have time to meddle with it again for a week.  
You can hardly imagine how much I want to hear from Joseph. Why do they not write?
 I did charge them to write every week at least. And with all my "pressure" I have written twice already.
 By the way - "Antoinette"'s brother Henry is very sick. He is a nice young man, and a particular friend of mine. Ought I not to write to him or some of the family? It is a duty to attend to the sick, is it not?

I have an immense amount of care and responsibility. These people do not probably know much, or they would not put so much upon so young an Engineer. 
However, they suppose it is all right, think they have got one of the very best men in the world, and as long as they are all satisfied, and nobody knows any better; why who should find fault?
  Well, I mean to take it easy this year. Who should, if not he who has his name up?
 But it is a great deal of work to organize, and "break in" a party of this kind, even of the best materials- to teach each one what he has to do, and how to do it; how to do it well and quickly too.

My Post Office Address at present is "Newbury N.H." I wish you would remember it, and act accordingly. Write to me, do write to me.

 This is the first day of August, very early in the morning or at least soon after four o'clock.
I almost wish it would rain a storm to day, as it looks so much like. We get wet every day, it showers so here around the Mountains, half of the time about; but no Storms for resting spells. Moreover the Manufacturing Company who own the Water power at the other end, have flowed the Sunapee Lake two feet higher than they have any right, which gives us a foot or two more of wading so we have quite a wet time of it between the Lake and the Mountain.
  The R.R. Company find me a first rate horse and hay for its keeping, for my particular riding. So last

Sabbath, there being nothing very inviting here about I rode out to Newport, some ten miles to Church

 They are about settling a Colleague to old Mr. woods but I do not like him half as well as I do the Old Man.
 I am very anxious to hear from Joseph. It seems almost an age since I left him. I think you ought to go up there and see and comfort him again this Summer. Why can you not. when you get Lucy & Jenny well trained? I do believe your presence would do Joseph good. It is dull, tiresome and monotonous there.
  Aug. 2 Well Alfred arrived here last night tired & sleepy enough, has not slept since he left home hardly, entirely unused to travelling you know Most used up, discouraged & homesick, terribly sorry he listed, I judge. However I encouraged him up. he had a good night's rest, and feels pretty "chirp" today.
  It seems they had written to me, from home before, but it going to Henniker, I have not yet received the Letter. Well I have got a grand party now, and feel pretty comfortable. It bothers me  though Joseph hardly wrote any thing by Alfred, and my brain is so full of every thing that I cannot think of what I want to ask Alfred, even if in the crowd I had time or chance.
 Well the dinner bell. pray do write to me

I.S.M.C.E.                                                                        Newbury, N.H. {at present}

circus

Milo Me. May . 5. 1851

Dear Mr. Friend & Brother Samuel

                              As you are not actively and urgently employed in business now a days, it is perhaps allowable for your friends to trouble and vex you with various commissions etc. etc.
 Now, I that, is "we", want a few grafted Fruit Trees from Uncle Nathaniel Harlow's Nursery.
 Charles has been all over Sebec, Atkinsons etc. today, and finds only, that there is no such thing to be found in the region.
Now, can you, should you like to, and will you, go to Uncle Nathaniel aforesaid, and procure, and superintend the forwarding of, a few such chice grafted Apple Trees? Perhaps it is not worth while to get very large ones. They may not do better.
The Number to be obtained to depend upon the price. If they cost $.25 each, I do not know as you had better get more than 7 [[picture of 6 dots in a circle with a 7th in the middle) or 12 at  at the outside. If only ninepence or a shilling, say 19 or two dozen. Not to exceed say $3.00 worth.
  If you will get and forward them, I will be personally responsible to you for the cost and your trouble etc. I.S. Metcalf {each Labeled I prefer Baldwins, but they say here, a variety  is better, to get scions, to graft from in future. Hardy kinds, Winter fruit.

[left-hand side] I suppose they can be sent up by a Team soon well packed.

we did think of you, my Dear Daughter, not a little last Friday the weather was so rough and rainy and that carraige so small I thought you could not lay down I fear'd you'd hardly live to get there - But James has just brought in your letter which much rejoiced us all -one from Antoinette too  Do be careful of yourself, so much company and excitement will leave you thro' almost any thing but remember the reaction just so far as you get above par, you will have to go below - keep yourself still & quiet if you want to get well. You didn't write a word about your cough.

 I took down my curtains to wash - and - out dropt Isaac's letter from Antoinette isn't it queer enough have you recei'd Mrs. Thaxter's letters yet. Charles went to day to carry Mr. Partridge & wife home, & after apple trees was gone till most night. I have been writing a letter to send to Ann - hope you will do the same before long. I am very glad you like your house and situation - if you could only be well how comfortable and happy - you would be. I hope you'll set about it and get well fast now. Do you want we should dig some roots and make you a Syrup when they get up so that they can be found. Abby Loring says white coronation cord to trim her little boys dresses - Tis ten o clock. I must go to bed, how the wind does blow - you may imagine but I cannot tell you how lonely we feel  good night

my love to your Mother Furber I can hardly feel reconciled to the thought of not seeing her again before she went away also to Mehitable & John tell them they must do a great deal

Dear Lucy Mother I believe has written of all our fears and over rejoicing , and also something of our condition to you You must be very careful, and not suffer excitement and company and a new place, and circumstances to elevate and trouble you if you ever want to get well again.

I have a commission for you, if you will to it. You know Miss Lizzie Doe is going away; she has been very kind to our folks, to Joseph, and I have those beautiful slippers she wrought

I want to make her a present of some nice book or some things of she will accept it. I have had no chance to see her. Will you see to it is able and get Eliab or Samuel to procure the thing, and you present it unto her in due and agreeable manner/

 In cost or amount any where to two or three dollars worth. Two. That Mrs. Knight's Memoir of Hannah More, if she has not it already, would be perhaps very appropriate, and decent.

Your task would be best of you were able to go out. As it is Eliab can do as well.

  If Eliab up to your house frequently, and daily, when he has time and opportunity:

Letters to me, come directed to Bangor. I am a little afraid they may lie there, as they did once before, although direct to Eliab's Box. Carelessness of Clerks. 

 I wish Eliab would see to it somehow. Letters may come there of much importance to me to see at once.

bottom of page possibly continued from another page of good in the "country they are going to"

Mother & Isaac
May 5.
[postmark]MILO Me. MAY 1  Samuel W. Furber Esq.    5

                                                     Bangor
                                                           Maine

Isaac May 1851
                                                                                   Milo Me. May 18, 1851

Dear Sister Lucy

       It is Sabbath Evening, and I guess most of the people have gone to bed or are about doing so. Thinking to be in haste tomorrow, and being now far from sleepy, I am writing.
By a pretty good sort of fellow apparently arrived here tother day a package of Fruit Trees not packed and a big bundle from you. The trees were little injured and are nice ones, and well set out. The price is thought rather high. $ .1/4 each being supposed common price in nurseries around Boston, and Grafted Trees when there have been any from Nurseries in this vicinity Atkinson etc. being ordered at $1/6 However we hope they will do well.
 I must tell you of the disease and sickness which afflict us in these parts of the world. 

To proceed categorically - 
The day we had some "Greens" for dinner, Mother called them very greasy, - but she and I ate them immensely. Soon Mother had much headache - vomiting - diarrhea. We think she is sickly yet. proof she does not talk very strong of washing tomorrow. Charlie also vomited & was sick. They soon said I was sickish, but I agreed with them so fully that they said I would not own it. Moreover strange to relate the infant baby who is not known to have eaten any Greens, vomited, and has been sick sundry days. Well day after Green day, James R.S.

helping Christopher. the hired Man, to plant, devoured very much of Bacon, named Ham, and boiled; And the said James vomited and was sore sick. Moreover the next day or two, his Sisters who eat no Ham Bacon, boiled fried or roasted, more jointly and severally though not synchronously attacked with much vomiting and sickness, and today could both more appropriately lie abed than attend Church. Moreover their Mother, who, in these times of disease and pain has honorably acquired the title of "Doctor", and whose services in that capacity have been extremely valuable: - the doctor, I say, although attending church half the day today on account of the imperative claims of the infant Sabbath School, is in reality sick herself!

What is to be done in this case?

We would like to advise with you.
I believe when the Cholera prevailed in Bangor, they went to Boston for Medical Aid. We do not like this course. We prefer to rely upon our own resources.

 In fact, in the present favorable and apparently convalescent condition of most or all of the sick, we should have great confidence in our eventual success. 

But --- I have myself been proposing to leave this place for parts known and unknown within a few days at the most.

Monday afternoon
 Isaac has expiated upon every subject of interest that I have no need to add much

So Dr. McRuen call'd all of his own accord did he? I should expect he would if he understands his own interest as any man ought to - Who shall decide when Doctors disagree. I should want now to see Dr. Snell and ascertain whether his opinion is in accordance with Dr. MC it need not hinder your employing Dr. MC if you prefer him.

 I have been looking in (& to the bottom) of every old chest, bank,  and drawer, handling over and arrangeing every old Garment, - "Coat Closets & rotten rags,, give some to Mr. Ricker cut up some for Carpet etc. etc. have not began to clean paint a bit, nor wash'd my Blankets, believe I shall get Mrs. Rocker to do the latter for I am not very well have some headache & Diarrhea but am as Isaac says Convelesant  Charles thinks he shall send the Cows down sometime this he thinks, if you can conveniently  he wants you should keep his Cow a week or two till she gets over her drive, (her milk would pay for keeping) She would sell better & you could tell better what she is worth he says She is a better cow than she looks to be i.e. she gives very excellent Milk when she is kept decently well.

Perhaps it is the 20th or 21st of May today. It appears this letter has not been sent. It will be tomorrow. I did propose to visit your place tomorrow. The work is not done, the wagon paint is not dry, the horse is not used.
Jas. R. Searles & myself talk of driving down a herd of neat cattle, two cows at least, but under above circumstances shall not go tomorrow.
If I have to wait until Monday, I shall probably be obliged to leave Bangor for Westward the same evening. Where then will be my visit to you? Would you in any event excuse it, under extreme promises of betterment? They hardly dare trust Jas. to drive the cows without someone else on road the same day. I shall come this week if WE Can. If you see Eliab, tell him at least not to send up any letters fro me on Monday if any there be .

                                                                                         True. I.S.

New York City, Sabbath, June 1, 1851

Dear Sister Lucy

        I suppose you expect me to write to you whether I have anything to say or not.
I wrote to Eliab from Montague, perhaps though I mailed the letter from somewhere else. In Boston I did little but to look after and order there Grave Stones. I think I have got something pretty nice, something that will look well. Nicest of Italian Marble, 4 in. thick - double thickness 24 in wide and 48 in high above socket stone.
 I staid at Montague one whole day and two nights, it being quite rainy. My Friend and former head Alfred R. Field lost his wife a fortnight since. She had been sick all winter of Consumption. A beautiful, very intellectual and accomplished woman. She was an Allen, a neice of ? Ett. Allen, formerly of Bangor. She lived with them in Bangor years ago. A splendid woman. Left two small children, perhaps 4 yrs. and 12 mos. or less. Friday I came to Hartford, spent several hours there it is a beautiful City. Found very little prospect of anything being done in this season or at present at least on the Hartford & Fishkill R.R. upon which I had the promise of a situation.

So I came on to New York City. Friday Evening. And stay over Sunday.
Yesterday among other Sight seeing I wandered over to Jersey City and called upon Jonathan Billington & wife
