[left-hand side]Dear Lucy do be especially careful of your health. You are not enough so. Were you not sick the morning I left. Almost every well person would be after your supper. If you did not perceive it in yr feelings, it must much injure you and prevent your getting well. Do be a good girl, write for your Mother to come down and follow her advices, only more so. Get Well.

Our New Cousin at Montague, Humphrey Stevens' wife, formerly Miss Isabella Bardwell of said Montague, is quite a Cousin, smart, bright girl, accomplished, quite a Country Lady, was "Belle of Montague", quite a good girl too I guess. Well, Humphrey is considerable of a man, there is a good deal of business in him, and he is well reported of among men, superior to Joseph A. in many respects. Our Mother & folks have never done him really justice, for prejudice in favor of Joseph A. upon his Mother's account.'   

  Mrs. J. K. Billington has got a Baby! Adopted one though, Harriet Celia by name. 5 mos. old, child of a Mr. Hunt an Englishman whose wife died lately. Very pretty but very small and perhaps sickly baby.
  I went over to Brooklyn this A.M. to hear Rev. Dr. R.L. Storrs, but found his pulpit occupied by the Rev. A. L. Stone of Boston, whereat I was not much displeased as I had been wanting to hear the said celebrated young Mr. Stone. Well he preached one of the most beautiful sermons I ever heard, Eloquent exceedingly. The Text was Davids "Charge to Solomon "Show thyself a Man" There is no question that Arthur L. Stone of Boston is Eloquent, how perfectly beautiful was that sermon. Every separate sentence was a gem, and a highly polished one too.
 What a great City this New York is! how full of wealth, and splendor and greatness, a city of palaces and princes, a crowning city, whose merchants are prices, whose traffickers are the honorable of the Earth.

And yet how full of Want & Misery, and Wretchedness, and poverty and suffering. - and worse than all, of Crime. how many thousand Gambling Saloons, gorgeous as palaces, but well called Hells. I do not know but a hundred thousand drinking places, from the filthiest of Irish Rum holes to the most splendid of gilded and marbled saloons, adorned with paintings and statues, every work of art and skill that can please the taste or tempt the eye.

 It is enough to set one thinking to walk in the streets here, here perhaps a reeling drunkard, spattered with mud, or with blood from contact with some curbstone or railing; there perhaps a party of miserable half naked emigrants, or of starving and shivering children, may be asleep upon some stone step or cellar grating; and then again crowds of beings beautiful as houris, decked with silks & jewels and brave attire, but whose "house is the way to hell, going down to the Chambers of death." ready to accost any one in the Street and if not replied to perhaps bursting out in horrible cussing and profanity. It is enough to make one disgusted with mere beauty for the rest of his life.
 I think I shall go to Albany tomorrow, probably to Utica, the next day, and perhaps to Canandaigua the day after, and so on. If I do not get pretty well stopped somewhere before, I may get to Westfield sometime the end of this week, and shall be very happy to find late letters from you there. Especially if Eliab has sent any thing to me since I left and I have not got it, or if he has any thing send, I wish you would write to Westfield this Week.
                                                                                                                 Affectionately I.S.

Brother Samuel, I think you had better call a consultation of Physicians to see what should be done for your wife, or decide what ails her. Old Dr. Rich, Dr. Snell or whoever in Bangor is supposed to know any thing. I did not think so much of it when in Bangor, but we not do want her to remain as she is now, that is certain. Cannot something be done. But above all no Violent remedies, calomel or scrychnine, blisters or douches.
[right-hand side]Brother Samuel


                                                           Samuel W Furber Esq      10
                                                             Bangor
                                                                              Maine

[postmark]ALBANY N.Y.  JUNE 3
[upside down]  Isaac June 1

Jonesboro, Oct. 12.

I have not any Envelopes, and so my previous letter or sheet ended very abruptly, and even without signature, after getting filled with a good deal of personal matters, my dealing Col. R.B. Mason Eng. in Chief, & how I am to be in Charge here only temporarily at 5, per diem, and to have 4. per diem & upwards, if I will stay, & had I better stay?
And ending with an Episode upon Sea bathing and Deer Isle.
You say Eliab went all that long way & so near me.
Well, he was, when at Chicago, within a few hundred miles of me to be sure, if you look merely as distance upon the map. But in reality I suppose he did not come more than a quarter part of the way from Bangor here, that is if you regard time and difficulty in getting here.

 However you need not fear that I can get away tolerably quick when I get ready. There is though a much nearer way than by Chicago. Just see by the Map how far south I am ; here at Jonesboro within 20 or twenty-five miles of Cairo, on the very southernmost point of free territory. Slave Country, not only East & West but N.E. & N.W. of us here. And you see it is but comparatively little way from Cincinnati, and that City by Modern Rail Roads etc. is getting pretty near to New York too.
  What do you write to the Mothers' Magazine about? I want to see the peice, I do. 

How do you like Ferdinand & Isabella?
If you had staid & not got sick, & prospered "continue"

your trip to Deer Isle might & undoubtedly would have done you far more than fifteen dollars good.

 It seems you had hot weather even in Bangor in the early part of September. Well you had better believe we had here - some - and kept it up pretty much to the latter part too.

It has made it very sickly in all this region too. Very unusual hot & very dry weather so late in the season. But now there has come rain and cool weather & frosts are about coming and health is revisiting the country immensely.

 I suppose lone ere this cold weather has come at Bangor, and undoubtedly no little frosts. Perhaps even now, certainly before this reaches you, the trees will have lost their leaves, and Winter will have come again, More at least than it will at all come here.

Do you really believe Eliab will stay at Brown's? Continue to stay there?
Will they not have to pay him well, better than they have done if he does?

 As for my address, it is perfectly proper and appropriate, most usual, and perhaps well, to put either "C.E." or "Cir. Eng." after the name.

It is a convenient handle to a name on paper, one that fairly belongs there, as much as A.M. would  if I were a teacher or such like, and may have an additional propriety or advantage, as a sort of Advertisement entirely unpresuming and appropriate.

If I were in a City I should perhaps prefer the "C.E." simply. In the country perhaps the "Cir. Eng."

 I have forgotten all about it before, but you remember you have been abundantly charged with and about it heretofore, about having Mother's Daguereotype taken abundantly whenever she was first in Bangor.
 I have told you & Eliab & Mother all about it I think. If there be considered as $5.00 {I have money in Eliab's & Samuel's hands, I believe} set apart for Mother's daguereotype for me. Very Large & in a very handsome case. Do not say I am extravagant. Why I shall ? it tomorrow clear!  

Well, Samuel, it seems you and I both talk about our first experience of sickness this season. Well, I hardly believe you ever felt quite so horribly stupid as a man with the ague, though doubtless you were much sicker.
Perhaps it is best to begin our experience in that line, before we get too old and crabbed to learn to bear it patiently. It is the lot of men. It has its blessings too. I know the little I have had has done me good if it has not made me more thankful & humble, it will make me more careful and attentive to health.  I am most afraid yr sickness must have affected & disarranged your business. I hope you are fully restored long ere this to health & strength. And careful not to over task your returning energies.

 Well, lots of lots of worthless rambling this is.

Write & constantly                                                                        Affectionately

                                                                                                               I.S.

Jonesboro, Union Co. Illinois
                                                                                                                                Sabbath, Nov. 2. 1851

Brother Samuel

  I find one page from you in the last letter from Bangor, whereat I am most obliged to you, especially as the page is a very good one.

I wish you would write such, or double them, more frequently than you do. I am inclined to think that I do rather more than my part of the writing for most all of you. Though to be sure I got in the habit of writing long letters with nothing in them. I write often when there is nothing to write, and oftener than I should, because I want to hear from you, and am afraid you will not write, if I do not.

You judge that I am in a good place, a place where there is room for a man to grow.

This is very true. There is room for a man to grow wherever there is room and opportunity for him to labor. Not the mere physical labor to be sure, like that of the brute; but a labor, or varieties of labor, demanding such intellectual effort as his mental state is equal to. And this it is usually far easier finding, even in the sphere in which every one finds himself, than most are apt to imagine.
There is here plenty of room to labor,  and plenty of room to grow. I am then & therefore very well situated here. I am likely, if I stay here to do well - to grow. But there is one objection,

one drawback. On the score of health. If one has not health he cannot work. In one respect this perhaps is usually, or eventually will be a more healthy country than the East, than New Eng. There is probably less fatal sickness, fewer deaths in proportion to the population than in New Englang or any similar country.
At the same time it is certainly an extremely sickly country; much more so than usual to besure, this season; but always in some sort. Everybody is sick more or less. Nine out of ten are sick really quite a proportion of the time. A mild sort of billious fevers, and this Miserable puny fever & ague, or "Chills & fever," as they call it here, are at work upon people about all the time. I have been sick three eighths or more, of the time for two months past. The old settlers, the "acclimated" have certainly fared no better on an average. A really healthy looking face, what we should call such at the East, is hardly to be seen. And just at this time, just after the Summer or Fall attacks of the Ague, and especially this Ague season, the "Natives" are the most miserable looking set of beings. And yet they are entirely free from fatal disease. There are far fewer deaths than there could be in any such class in New England.
There appears to be no such thing as Consumption here, or hardly any of the diseases most fatal at the East.

  If I had got the appointment of Division Engineer here permanently, I should have been obliged to grow. And yet I think I could have succeeded in it. If Ormsby could keep the place six months, I certainly think I could for six years! 
                                                                                       I.S. Metcalf

Isaac
                                                                                                    Jonesboro, Union Co. Illinois
                                                                                                     Sabbath. Nov. 9. 1851.

Dear Sister

  Letters reached me on the 5 inst from Bangor and Milo. being one from you. Samuel & Eliab of Oct. 1. One from you of Oct. 4, and one from Mother and Eliab at Milo, Oct. 6-10  reaching here at once via Mt Hawkin's Post Office, Perry Co.
 You had all just heard of my Ague, sickness etc. and all troubled and advising me to leave here at once. Which would be no sort of use, the advice being a few months to late. I may just as well stay here this winter. It is a healthy country enough in the Winter Season. And it is perhaps better to leave in the Spring than in the Fall.
Your idea of the ague is perhaps tolerally correct.
When a chill comes on, one not accustomed or watching for it might not notice, certain symptoms of blue lips purple nails & cold fingers, till he finds himself suddenly shaking.  It is rather queer, than very bad, perhaps in a very hot day, or sitting by a big fire, all wrapped up in clothes, to be shivering with cold for an hour or two, and without really feeling very cold either. Soon the patient commenced drinking a pailful or at least a pitcher full of water. and before long the cold & shivering gradually, almost imperceptibly, passes into a burning fever all over, usually accompanied by more or less of head ache & back ache.

This is decidedly tedious, and vast amounts of cold water internally, or cold wet cloths on the head, chest or hands, afford only an extremely temporary alleviation.

By and by, the patient begins to sweat, the fever gradually passes off, and he feels simply weak and sleepy, till an other chill come on, usually just twenty four, or just forty eight hours. You speak of its affecting the spirits. I do not know it is has any tendency to produce the blues, or make one melancholy; it makes one too dull and stupid even for that, too much disinclination to mental effort even to feel homesick! Somebody's expression, I have heard somewhere describes it exactly. One feels like a 'Stewed fool.'

It requires considerable mental vigor to rouse up and take necessary means to stop the disease, or as it is always called, 'break' it -, "break the ager."
This is usually very easily done. The great Medicine always accomplishing this at once is Quinine, which you know is a powerful extract, a white precipitate, from the Peruvian Bark. It is the most powerful of Tonics, and the very perfection of bitter. The stomach is always a little out of order, from some derangement of the Liver. A dose of some purgative is always administered first. The doctors always prescribe some form of Mercury as most affecting the Liver. Say a dose of Calomel & Jalap, or rhubard; or else a blue pill & any gentle purgative, and then ten grains of Quinine every hour four hours before the coming chill. The Country people however have a prejudice against Quinine, besides that is very expensive

costing the doctors themselves some five or six dollars an ounce. Many simply let the disease run. The dull stupid feeling between whiles gradually nears out, the patient recovers a great appetite; perhaps is able to work well on the alternate days, and some have it so for months or even a year. And some doctors cure it with all sort of bitter roots & barks. 
For myself, one or two shakes and fevers, answers very well, and I am quite resigned to take a Quinine, if it is bitter, and throw it off.

  Is Samuel going to build upon the lot he has bought of Uncle Nattagniel Harlow. 

I would like to help eat some of your "Milo Chickens" cooked as you cook them. Us suckers cook chickens it is rather hard feed.  I wish I could describe the process of getting a meal of victuals here. 1st kindle a fire, 2d ? to door with rifle & shoot the chickens. {Every animal is shot here, beef, hog, or chicken} and a chicken is never killed over five minutes before it is cooking. It is always cut up and boiled, and all parts, You will always find the feet on the platter, and often the head! You will hardly believe this but it is a serious fact! very much so it seemed to me at first, when I could not eat my dinner for it.

 Another queer thing is that butter is always churned as it is used, not before hand; one part of getting a Meal Meal of Victuals is churning a pint bowl of butter.

The last thing before setting the table is stirring water into a dish of Corn Meal, and putting it before the fire to

warm a little for bread.
I do not dare to write but about half. and have probably already overstepped the limits of your credulity.
It is fact however, the common corn bread of the country is merely the white corn meal (lucky if not mushy) and water, merely warmed through fairly and laid on the table.
Still the Natives say they like it. I can eat it!

 People here do not go to Church much. Today is a little rainy: and muddy. The whole congregation at the Methodist Church was 12 all told Baptist about the same. This evening a Lutheran service there mere 13.
                                                                                                 Truly
                                                                                                          I.S.M.

[upside down] Samuel, I am very glad to hear that you have so well recovered health and strength. Be careful of it. I hope your business did not suffer materially.  How is your Mill likely to turn out? Do you keep it running in the winter?

Your Mother's death is a great loss, yet you cannot mourn as those without hope. You know that your loss is her gain. It perhaps seems hard that she was far away. Consider though the pleasure that meeting her children at the west must have been to her, and the consolation to them to have her with them again.                                                            Sincerely

Isaac
                                                                                                                                     Jonesboro, Union Co. Illinois       
                                                                                                                                     Thursday, Nov. 27. 1851   

Dear Sister Lucy

           It is Thanksgiving Day. - Thanksgiving evening. You would hardly believe it it though of here, by any external manifestation I have seen today.
 Thanksgiving, I judge, is not observed at all in this region. The same day was regularly appointed by our Sicker Gov. French, but I guess not one hereabout remembered it.

I breakfasted early, had a horseback ride of three miles or more by about daylights, worked & rode in the woods. {Southern, Illinois thick woods} till dark, then rode to town got supper, worked in office a spell, and then come in to my Landlord's comfortable sitting room, and take the rest of my Thanksgiving in writing a bit to you, interrupted only by the gabbling of a couple Sucker women serving in the same room.  Will that do.    
I received a good nice letter from you and Eliab last night written Prov. 1 I judge; Mailed Nov. 2.
Your letters are longer reaching me I suppose for being directed Mount Hawkins. than if direct to Jonesboro. It sometimes takes them a week to get from Mr. Hawkins here.
As for your worrying about me: it is much to be lamented if you have not done it to good advantage; I believe I have done all I could towards, have certainly furnished you with the most full and detailed statements of all the facts involved.
I expect Mother has got back to Bangor by this time, has she not?
Is Samuel employed at his Mill through the Winter

Samuel, it seems. has not only bought his House lot, but is preparing to build. Well, good luck.
The plan is very much the same as that of the house you now live in, is it not? That is, according to the sketch on the back of your letter. How does it differ? I should think it very convenient house for a small family. well adapted for comfort, rather than show, and at the same time rather economical for the amount.
I highly approve of Eliab's Upham & Conquest of Mexico. but should recommend the Gammon  in "broken doses," as the Doctors do Quinine; say instead of occasionally =, only "Semi=occasionally!
I supposed Mary Tower was to be married and go away as a Missionary before this time. How is it?
Is she engaged to ___ or not? If not, you will of course let me know; being in want of a wife, the information would be of interest to me. Mary is an extra nice little girl, and no mistake, and what is bad, such are scarce, - especially where ill fortune always calls me.
Whether I shall stay here longer than till Jan. first is quite uncertain. If I leave then I expect my best course will be to go around by way of New Orleans at any rate, even if I do not conclude to stay there a while at least.
I was intending to write to Eliab tonight, but I must put it off until Sabbath I think, and also to Anne from whom I also received one last night.
Samuel I believe I shall not write to this time.
I expect he owes me one or two now. This is half sheet but I am still in spite of that

                                                                                                                      Aff. I.S.

Isaac
                                                                                                                      Jonesboro Union Co. Illinois
                                                                                                                             Tuesday, Dec. 23. 1851

Dear Mother & Sister Lucy

                                   Your good letter of Nov. 17  23. came duly to hand on Saturday Dec. 20, somewhat delayed by going to Mount Hawkins as have been most of your letters.

About the same time I received also letter from East Hampton Mass. from Eliab, where it seems he is now attending School, after a pleasant visit among the folks at Royalston Warwick, Northfield and Montague. I have just written to him. Probably this going to School is the very best thing he could do in a few month.
I think you Lucy took a very sensible woman's view of the matter in your last letter.
What appears to trouble him most is as to what he shall do in the Spring, or when he leaves school. I would judge East Hampton a pretty good place for him. 
I judge he did not go to Albany: At least he did not mention it to me.
You Laugh Lucy at this "Great Western waste." I tell you the world does not begin to realize yet what it is , or to be. They talk of the "Mighty Waste," of the greatness of the Valley of the Missippi; "the Centre of our Country" etc. etc., but they have not yet begun to realize its destiny.

The Great West, has but barely begun to grow.
Sail along these rivers, often a hundred Miles, even yet through an unbroken wilderness, then consider that the whole is the very richest land in the world: unsurpassed even by the Valley of the Nile. Tenfold the whole present population of the United States, will be settled in the Valley of the Missisippi, before its resources will be fairly tried. The whole commerce of the world now hardly exceeds that soon to be carried upon the Mississippi and its branches. And calling the country sickly will not prevent it. It is sickly now only as being uncultivated, and unimproved. The lands that now loaded every autumn with six inches or a foot of decaying leaves, make an unhealthy country, would do no harm if the vegetation was in the shape of one hundred bushels of corn to the acre regularly taken off.
You and Mother and Anne} from whom, I have just this now received a nice letter} and all, seem very glad that I did not get $3000.00 per Annum Salary, because I suppose, it would keep me in this ill Agueish country.
What will you say if I should conclude to stay at only half that Salary!
Last Week was about the coldest weather for some days that they ever have here. Thermometer down even below zero once.
I was out down on Cache River with a

party of men living under tents, all the time. I called it very comfortable: good camp bedsteads or cots. best Mackinaw blankets, and abundance of firewood.  But the weather was too cold for suckers altogether. Some of them could hardly keep warm chopping! In fact I saw more than once that week, farmers out getting up Wood, having kindled up a fire in the woods to cut down a tree by!  And really some in my Party froze their feet while chopping.

I believe I kept some of the alive only by so much laughing at them. I enjoyed it much. I expect I have now got about through with out of door work for the present.
 I am very glad Mother that you have got back to Bangor, both on Lucy's account and your own. I am inclined to think you can be more comfortable there than at Milo, especially if that Store smokes as it did last Winter. 

Neither of you wrote any thing about Lucy's health in the last letter; so I take it for granted that it properly improving.

 The Cold Weather last week closed up with ice both the Ohio & Mississippi Rivers. Do you see I can not get home now if I wished, except perhaps to go around by the way of New Orleans and the Atlantic.

Samuel, I suppose has gone into the woods Scaling. Where abouts does he go and how much?
I presume he comes out every week or two, does he not?
Does he keep a horse?
What time do you expect to get the new home finished?
I want to know where to find you if I should happen to visit Bangor any time within a few years.
Well bless you all

                 I. S. Metcalf

P.S. Dec. 23r
I wish you all a Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year          

                                               Sincerely I.S.

Dear Mother                                                                           Bangor 1835

  When I started there was two other in the stage so that I set on the front seat which soon made me sick when we got to nr Hoxies I got onto the back seat but I was sick all the fore-noon and vomited some - could eat nothing at. It was drifted bad and we had to get out and help the stage along! sometimes went out into the field 3 times to get along and once while going out of the road one runner got onto the bank and the other into the gutter the sleight upset with me in it but there was so much snow that it fell very easy. I got out and we lifted it up, and went on. I was very cold my boots were so damp and I had to keep my head out of the window all the time an I should be sick. I got to Mrs. Parkers at about 5 o clock cold enough! Mrs. P. keeps a  girl and 4 boarders besides Grandmarm as they all call her they keep 3 wood fires (some times 4) besides the boarders Mr. Blood and wife Mr. Stackpole and wife both of whom find their own fuel which is coal They keep no cow Mr. Blood has a home but he takes care of it himself. I go to a public bright school Mr. Pomeroy and Mrs. P. both thought that I had better if I could. (for It is a select school no one can go to it without they know so much and a committee examines them There was two other examined at the same time that I was one passed and the other did not. There is about 30 scholars the Masters name is Worcester. The school is in an large brick building with a steeple between Mr. Pomeroys house and Meeting hose there are 2 other schools in it the common school and a school for young men apprentices Albert Stubb goes to it I have bought a Goulds Latin Grammar for which I gave .92 cents & Mr. Worcester says that I better look over Smiths Arithmetic some what and then study Algebra. I saw and split the wood and have to come down to the stores and market and so on - have to be pretty bust. I have been all round every where most and I cannot get that Jacket cut some said that it could not be done without paper others said that they would not that it would tear and that  they could not chalk cannot you make it from that coarse one for this one will not last till Spring I fear Teusday they out another stove into the Schoolroom for it is very large and one would not keep It warm it is in the 2 story and there is 2 other schools in as much room under it. Lydia? Grant Mrs. P. girl is page torn And she is a green brittle rest of page scorched? browned? torn

Is Charles goind to keep that school has he killed the cow and hogs how much did they weigh has he got the shed full of wood how does the school stove work I saw Hector Sargent Saturday he said that you were all well and that he was carrying up the stove and then drove on I suppose that he was in a hurry for it was past 2 in the afternoon. Mrs. P. has got working? stove in her kitchen but it is larger than yours the kitchen is very small so I am afraid that yours will not keep that room warm her though has not got but little funnel, it goes right into the chimny with one knee by the way how much do you have Mrs. P. was sick confined to be teusday but she is about well now Mr. Natty of the Hammond street preached last sundy in the forenoon and Prof. Woods in the afternoon I went to sabbath school my teacher is Mr. Gilbert he boards at Mr. T Harlows and teaches the children Charles is a pretty roguish little fellow and is up here a good deal I dont know but I should want that coarse Jacket for I have so? Them black stocking here not put in the trunk and I want them I want a comforter also there is no class in Blakes Philos they all use Comstocks you must write on the other leaf of this and send it tonight

Eliab must write so that I can see how They send their love and soforth

These mixed Clothes look odd they were them so small I cant stop to write any more so you must write soon

                                                                                                  Your Affectionate Son
                                                                                  Isaac S. M.

Dear Mother                                                                                       Wednesday Jan 24  1836

  I received your letter last night when I get home from school I am very well and have been over page torn  I came home and so is all of Mrs. P.s family The measles are very prevalent here. page torn and a good many have died of them. here it is said that there was not so much snow in the 2 last winters put together And it has been very cold indeed too but since the 20th: has been warm and the snow has gone off fast During the cold weather I had to be pretty busy and work pretty hard but warm weather page torn burn half so much Now that the stove is out of the kitchen it takes page torn wood most as much as in our kitchen at home I think that I get along pretty well in my studies I have got a little ways into the latin reader I get a lesson in the reader in the fore noon and one in the Grammar in the after noon I think that by the time school is done I shall have got along so that I can make a pretty good progress alone We have got more than 1/2 ofthroug the Philosiphy and are now reviewing I joined a class in  Smiths Arithmetick when I came here had got as far as the Rule of three we have been through it and are now reviewing it so as to be ready for examination We parse 3 times a week and recite grammar 2 ? The examination is to commence Wendnesday page torn How long it will be I dont know the common page torn about the same time The apprentice school left off last week I have not page torn William Bean at all I dont know as it is worth the while to write so much if I am coming home so soon. I get along pretty well in my studies & so forth. You tell me to wrote every minute incident well then I have got to build the fire Monday morning I have not built it but once before this time have to have a good fire before 8 o clock  I have to get up about light two fire to build which takes some time  then as often as every other morning, I have to run down to the market or store pretty lively when I get a chance You can see pretty plainly I guess that I have not improved much in Writing but the master does not pretend to teach writing and what with every thing else I have not much time page torn From Your affectionate Son page torn

Boston Jan. 25 1837
Dear Mother
I ought to have written before I suppose, but I kept putting it off all the time till now. However I am going to set about now for I must go Saturday. I have nothing to do but to saw the wood and help Almeda what I can by tending the baby &c. I have studied some at home have wrote through 2 of Fosters writing books and begun another and looked over Philosophy and Grammar some. I also go down to Ann's school-room sometimes noons, where she shows me how to write &c, as she has her dinner there all but Wednesday and Saturday. O by the way I want to know if you think I improve in writing. The baby is beginning to sit alone tell Lucy that she has now been sitting on the floor half an hour play-ing with that rosewood ring that she and James cracked last winter rolling it from the table. Also tell Mayo that I am in Mr. Bash's class in the sabbath-school and that he gave every one of his scholars a little book (Baxters Call) New Years day which was Sunday. I take turns staying from...
[upside down] my health is pretty good this winter page torn am obliged to hire any washing done the cost from 40 to 90 cents a fortnight and I do the baby's I went down to Charles last week and found I was in the midst of the small pox there was a whole family oposite Miss Metcalfs that had it was near Spring/ & Popular Streets and it is now in this part of the city. I was not frightened but thought best to vaccinate my babe and now she is cross with it. Isaac has a good deal of time in which he might study but you know it is impossible for a boy to make so much progress alone the time he spends helping me varies according to what I have to do from half an hour to 3 or 4 hours in the course of the day and evening but it is at odd jobs he goes every day when he wishes to study with Ann but sometimes she cannot spare with him so you see that though his advantages are not as good as we had hoped yet they are greater than many have his religious priveleges are really very great but I am afraid he will not improve as he might. I have had him stay two Sabbath evenings for me to go to meeting the rest of the time he would go and every Tuesday evening he goes and occasionally Monday eve. and once a month the young men are to meet at Mr. Boll's for moral, intellectual, and religious improvement and he can join the association. He is in Mr. Bush's class and he is a very devoted pious man but with all these advantages he does not seem to feel more than he has done the importance of the one thing.

from meeting to tend the babe, (half of every other sabbath). The baby was christened the first day of Jan. the Minister called her Lucy Al-me-i-da. I have read 1  Harlan Page 1 It was printed an purpose and distributed to the Church members New-Years-day so that James had one. Ann has bought me a Bailey's Algebra for 67 cts which I believe explains it more than Colburns so that I think I can get along with it very well. I have also for about a month split most of Mr. Thaxter's wood. I have spent about most $17-18 3,25 for passage Boots 2,06 1/4 Shoes 1,06 1/4 Jacket 6,50 Vest 1,95 Cloak 1,27 1/2 How much is that Eliab? Then suspenders - carring trunk- have cutting /writing books - Slate = 3 X 12 1/2 . 87 1/2 Paper for Journal 16 2/3 besides Algebra etc. The rest $10 lacking - that she has paid for books paper etc. for me, I have lent to Ann. tell Mayo he must write to me soon for I want (dreadfully) to know all about the what the Hay went for the threshing Machine the school and the Lyceum. There has not been either snow or sleighing (to. hunt) here yet till 
Ann talks of writing soon page folded upbe disappointed if she does not find time  page torn time.

last Saturday 21st, - the 21st and 22 there was a real snowstorm I have hardly seen any snow before since I come from (Donn East). You say that Charles keeps a school in Sebeck, does he come home every night?? how much does he have? and Mayo how do you and Eliab get along with the Chores and go to school? have you a good school? do you go to Lyceum? do you naher the cattle at the river now? have you got any lambs or bossy yet? How much Cedar does Charles get out this winter? ask Lucy if she wants to see the baby? Mrs. Thaxter has page torn young canary birds just learning to fly but Poll. was sent away the day that I got here so I saw him not. I went to the Antislavery anniversary Wednesday it was held in a loft over the stable in the rear of the Marlbro' Hotel. they said that there was not a meeting house or hall in which they were allowed to meet in Boston Amos Dresser that was dressed so at Nashville was there and gave an account of his lynchment ! Almeda was going to write but she kept putting it off so that I guess that there is not much room. I had a poor pen. Write Isaac M.

My Dear Friend

    As I have a convenient opportunity I think I will wrote you a few words. I was intending to have gone over to Mr. Dennetts this evening with Charles but 

[rest is upside down] My Dear Son
page folded down the last next I have had nothing this long time that has troubled me so much as the thought that you are stuck down in the cellar which we will so little opportunity of getting knowledge of ?kind or lack for business opportunity of any kind and the fear that you do not feel the importance of turning every moment that you have for yourself to advantage in improving your mind remembering as that you lack what most people would think wholy indespensible a good teacher and have to depend on yourself you must double your diligence must be indefatable in your exertion and what is more, infinitely more, fear that you are oversimplifying your previous religious privelege.
you know that you are by nature sinful and that your heart and soul prone to suit? that it only the grace of God that it can be renew'd and made holy and that the holy spirit that still small voice is prompting you back to God by ? for that renewing grace and if you follow the suit? more than you have the promise ? of the most high ? god which is sure that you shall not seek in vain ? but if you do turn a deaf ear to him who is waiting so long to be gracious what can you expect but that your lot will be cast upon you ?                        Jan 25, 1837

Dear Mother                                                                        ?          Friday Jan 17th

  Marshall Hill has just called here and left a Bundle etc. from you. We, that is, Ann and I were very glad to get it indeed. We have been expecting sometime, but have made out pretty well considering I have been going to write for some time, as I was somewhat in want of my Gloves, old Frock coat etc. but they have come now, nicely as can be.  We are getting along as well as might be expected, I think, this cold weather. I guess that Ann, Notwithstanding her, but, if, a and, has a very good School and moreover is doing grandly in it, and will make a favorably impression. However I am afraid she has most to hard a time of it, with so many Scholars. I am getting along pretty so so in my studies. We have got all over into Cicero a Greek too etc. etc. We, that is this time, we High School boys! have got up a kind of a Club, of 20 or 30, which meet once a week, evenings, in the school room, for Declamation or Debating, improvement I am tuck'd? in for one of the Officers!!! We have met 3 or 4 times Declared a Debated at a great rate. It would be a very good thing, especially for me, if we could sustain it properly a keep order but I suspect it will soon fall to bits, for All boys, especially Bangor boys, except Poet Roberts 2 or 3 others and myself!!! are so flighty and fond play and fun and nothing else that be. I suppose it will be all finish soon. 
 I suppose I ought to be very thankful for having such a good place etc. a everything else. I have a excellent place, lamps enough a a warm rooms good chance to study evening a only have to go but a few roads? to School.

While Eliab has to go far to School and the cold mornings a thinks no great nice light all the evening to study by. I have or can have a lamp, and place all to myself every evening, to study and write or anything and  Excellent good School, few roads? off and everything Meeting a S. School etc.etc. etc. etc. etc.
However Home is home if it even so homely a I do almost envy the nice tother room by the fire. Eliab dont know what it is not to be at home.

I really expected Isaac a good letter from Brother Eliab in the Bundle. Why dont he write, I wonder? How does Eliab get along in all of his studies? Does he Study? really. Does he study enough? he ought to a very good deal. I study or write or something, till about 11 every evening bout. I want to know all about hom every they gets along nowadays. Here most folks been almost out of patience waiting for snow. It has been Sleying here all the time some, but I think that there is less up in the country 4 or 5 feet in Mass
[right-hand side] I thought when I was at home I should not write such a letter or this very soon again O dear
[bottom of page upside down]Is not this cold weather about this time? How much wood pile have you hauled up? Eliab How many times has the wood shed blown over lately? I really meant to have written a regular good set letter about this time but. I dont know as you can read this or if you can I am heartily ashamed of this.
I want very much that you should write to me much and Eliab must write too. You did not write.
[left-hand side]Isaac Bangor

                   Jan 19, 1839

Has Charles finger got well? What do the horses do this winter? go to singing school? he! he! Has a Mr. Chipman, Temperance from N. York lecture at Milo yet. He a few great congregations here Names of Scholars Bangor City High School Fall Term October 1839 Bangor

Bangor Saturday April 13th 1839

Dear Mother

                               I am admitted to the Bangor City High School. it was not till yesterday that the Committee decided whether I could be admitted. Mr. Abbot Chairman of the Committee told me that all of the committee felt a great sympathy for young men who wished to get and education who were "not wealthy" , and Mr. Wakefield told me that all of them wished to admit me if they could lawfully. I think that they are very pleasant folks at the Me. Worester's. I have been to see "friend" Hatch' and got my hair cut also bought a pair of suspenders, the man called them braces, on Thomas hill: I went up there yesterday, they have got 3 buildings ~ feet long made of rough boards with hole at the ridgepole to let the smoke out the beds are boards, nailed up at the sides [like births in a vessel] filled with Straw. Three or 4 old ? soldiers have arrived today. I met Mr. Pomroy in the street yesterday he did not know me at first, but turned suddenly round and  said "do you know me?" and then "is it Isaac?" so I tould him it was etc. etc. etc. He was very sociable etc.

13th Sun. eve. Went to meeting and S.S.  Mr. and Mrs. W. go to "The Church" as they call it  Par eminence I spose meaning the Episcopal. The girl goes to the Methodists. Mr. Wakefield and I to Mrs. Pomroy's. This afternoon a company of soldiers came marching right by the meting house Drum fife

Monday morn. I have been to school. Frank Brown goes and there are 4 or 5 who went when I was here before in the school. I want a First Class Book and Colburns Algebra immediately. It rains very hard to day and has rained or snowed almost every day since I have been here and I have no umbrella. I must have some kind of a Packet. this one will be all gone by July if I dont, bringing in wood and so forth, it begins to near already, the old white jacket would be better than none. This would last a good while if I had another to slip on before and after school. It is a great deal more in the fashion to have wide collars turned over than it was 2 or 3 years since. Surtouts now have caper mostly, and neither surtouts or frockcoats have pockets before. The high school is now kept in a new building made on purpose. boy's school below girls above I have not much to do here yet, only to take care of the cow, wood and water. Mr. Parker is very sick, is not expected to live I believe. I guess it would be well to send Comstocks Philosophy - also if convenient. Why does not Joseph get home spose? I need a penknife somewhat I guess that the steamboat will come clear to Bangor Wednesday.

                                                                                                               Affectionately etc. etc.
                                                                                                                                      Isaac S. Metcalf
                                                                             P.S. I want a dictionary
                                                                                                           I.S.M.

[right-hand side] Bangor Isaac

                              Apr. 13 ' 39

Bangor April 21st 1839

The class in Latin dont go fast enough
Dear Mother

                         I suppose that before this time you know that Joseph has at last arrived safe in these parts. I did not see him till he had been here 6 hours. I had given up the search and suppose he did not come in the Boat. I shall feel much more at east now I have some books. the books were very cheap but miserable paper and miserable binding, in the dict. there is   pages missing and  other pages put in 2ce. which bothers some. I want to know whether I had better send to Boston for a Greek Grammar and Reader and perhaps Cicero which I shall want pretty soon or buy them here.

Since school began, 1 week, we have finished the first book of the Aeneid 200 lines. I had been over it before but not looking at it for so long I find that I cannot learn it any faster than I could at first hardly
I get up in the morning about 5, have 2 fires to make I have to bring water, about 4 pails per diem from the yard across the street, take care of the Cow, bring in wood etc. I have abut finished the wood cutting spliting carrying into the Barn and so forth.

Teusday, What beautiful weather, dont  it set C. and E. to work. I want a Palmlead hat, my head is to plagy hot. I have been carrying away the banking from the house since Joe was here. If it holds this weather I shall not want a jacket. Mr. Worcester has considerable of a Library, but a large part of it is in foreign languages, French, Spanish, Italian, Latin, Greek etc. etc. Most of the time he is in the house he is reading some french monk and smoking a pipe with his dict. by him he has read thro one work since I've been here, and is now reading the  Life of Louis 14th in 4 tomes.

[right-hand side] Aint this a good solid letter?

Wednesday I met with quite an accident last night, I went down town to get 3 gallons of Molasses in a great Jog, Demijohn, covered with wicker whatever you call it. Well I got it filled, it was heavy and as I was carrying out I set it down on the step lightly I thought but it happened that the rats had gnawed off the stuff leaving the bottom bare on one side, when I set it down that side broke and : then the Molasses started; O dear! howsomelever I caught it up, turned it the other side up and carried in to the store and emptied it into a pail; spilt about a quart, I guess Nath. Harlow one of the Bradford Harlow's sons died Monday & of an brain fever I beleive. The funeral was at 9 1/2 this morning he had formerly been a member of the C.H.S. so the  school adjourned to attend to attend the funeral. he was buried at Mount Hope.
5 oclock. A little while ago Nat. Hobbs came into the yard  where I was to work, bringing you know what, !!!!!!!? That is the very fellow I've been hunting ater so long, says he The folks were all gone away visiting etc. etc. And it would not do for me to leave the house, no how. So I told him about the Trunk, he said he had a dretful load already, but if he could fasten it on, he would try and take it. Well, I hastened to examine my treasures, which were very acceptable, the jacket was very needful, the stockings were very nice, the books, knife and so forth very convenient, however the lead pencil was broke and shivered so as to spoil 1/3 of it.
You done well, moving towards home!! one leg little stiff! I guess the jacket will answer very well, Och! och. I set out to try it on to see, but what do you think I found in the pocket!?! ? Och ha! ha! You say to send by Charles wherefore did Nat Hobbs bring it here? The Umbrella is at the Browns Frank will bring it over. I dont know but a frock would be suitable expedient etc.

A white cotton one or a white cotton jacket would do very well to wear to school in warm weather
It seems to me Joe, that your letter is rath dry barren be on at least small and fumbling. I want to know greatly how the Work play the lambs, calves pigs, cow, horses, sheep, hens, wood pile, manure heap, plowing, planting, sowing, ferrying Evvvveeerrrryyyyooonneee get along and prospers So I tell you Joe you better fly round, likewise Eliab also YOU (plural) must Write Write WRITE and Write of I dont C.H.S.

                                                                            Affectionately I.S. Metcalf 
                                                                                                      Bangor

[left-hand side] Friday Is this the same seed cakes, that were left when you failed? 
P.S.  Mr. Hobbs was gone before I could send by him, and did not take the Trunk. 
Friday, I would send this by them, Levi Wilkinson 
I want  Palmleaf hat pretty soon great by
If I dont I shall have the head ache all the time when it is warm, a fine one,
Could not Charles bring one down sometime when he comes?
Mr. Worcester has engaged a peice of land " 1/2 acre", over the other side of the road. It is covered with stumps, bushes etc. very uneven he is to have it two years for clearing I believe Going to work on it tomorrow, clearing. I have done 2 Jobs already for Charles Harris amount $.20! splitting wood
Where are my shoes I expected them in the bundle, I shall need them as soon as warm weather. My coat begins to wear out especially the lining. In haste, I.S. Metcalf

Bangor Thurs. May 16th 18  39

Dear Mother

 I wrote a letter last Sunday, to you but not having any opportunity to send it till now I concluded to add to it and for that purpose cut the seal open but behold! I had written so much before that there was not even a corner left! Just then I spied this piece of paper see what I did with it!

I cant see why some of you dont write to me. It's a dretful long fortnight since Charles was here it will be 2 weeks soon We have got through the 2d book of Aeneid in Virgil. 2d book has 800 lines, 1000 from where we began. At first we got only 20 to 30 lines per day, now 50 to 60 Is not that old quid of tobacco peice wrote off, in the house somewhere I wish I had it to speak here I have not had to speak or write yet the new scholars look on awhile, it shall have to a fortnight from yesterday after that every other week about  Did not the rain teusday make a little freshet. There is quite a rise of water here. I expect it put a stop to farming operations for a few days. I am impatient to know all about the spring mark, and whether the wheat was saved before the rain or not etc. etc.  Is the fence put up over east for the sheep pasture? or do they run in the morning, as last year?  We (I and Mr. W) have not plant of our own labors yet, been sowing garden, I have dug some holes to put

13 Isaac May 16 '39
the manure in for Potatoes, and a going tomorrow to making fence. The patch is going to be rather hard hoeing, have to hole the ? instead of furrowing What shall I write com. about there is no common subject, even one writes what he is a mind to, about 1/2 this term have been about the Adriatic? wars, and one C. Roberts the poet as he is called spoke a piece of his poetry of his own make about it. I want Joe. and Lucy and all of you to tell something I almost wish I was to home sometimes. It is not so pleasant here as to home to work on the farm, I shall have to be a farmer I guess  Old Mr. Sewall of Farmington, Mrs. W. Father has been here lately a spell Francis Dennet is in Bangor I dont know for what. It rains again You must all write to me Mother, Joseph, Lucy et Eliab often also, once a week or so 
Sat. 18th There is a great many day to day 250 bbls. Flour, H.L. Seed, lots of Furniture all kinds Crockery, Dry goods, etc. etc. 
22d a whole store full, to be sold. Never mind the books!!!

Bangor Sun. June 9. 1839

Dear Mother

                Mrs. Parker died last night about 11 oclock. A month ago. she was not expected to live a week, and she has been declining ever since; Mortification began to take place Thursday, the doctor said that nothing but the very irritation of the disease kept her alive so long. She had a very painful sickness and a very hard death from the nature of the disease. She has suffered a great deal of pain, and her features are very much distorted; wasted to a skeleton with her long illness. She has had the same disease a year or two, but was taken very sick the first of June. Notwithstanding the painful nature of the disease, she has had her reason all the time about, her mind wandered a little for a day or two before her death.

Mon. P.M. Mrs. Parker's funeral was today, 3 P.M. there was a good many present, Mr. Pomroy of course. She was buried at Mt. Hope 2 1/2 miles from the city; the whole family, even "Granmam" went up; I was left to keep of the house for a long time before, but she thought she must go up to Mt. Hope with them. I think she is smart for so old a lady. Mr. Nath. Harlow or "Uncle Natty" has been married again lately! the time I believe. He is not in very good repute with Mr. Walker, I guess. Charles Henry Johnson is apprenticed to him; Mr. W. likes him, so do I.
Has it not been fair weather at Milo for  3 or 4 weeks? the last real fair day here was the 26th of May I believe. It is said that a great many even of potatoes have rotted in the ground! I want very much to learn all home you have prospered, suffered, etc. etc. etc. etc.   If Joe dont write---  IS
[right-hand side] Isaac Bangor

                             June 9, 1839

Wed. June 12th P.M.                                                                                    Fair day
No school this afternoon. I spoke this forenoon a "touch of the sublime"! what I found in the Newspaper I have spoke but once before, and wrote but one compore subject, Early rising! We commenced the 7, book today in Virgil; or along pretty well I guess got past through the Algebra; where it is tebly hard. I wish I had one of those little small trunks, if it had a key/ to put in my desk at school; the desks have no lock, and it is sometimes very convenient  to keep compositions etc. etc. in the, which every one is not wanted to see: All of them boys have a little trunk box or something of the kind. I guess one of those little trunks would go in, and it would be very convenient.
I am going to send home these suspenders as they dont stretch any yet! hardly, I wish you would knit me some more long ones. If Charles dont bring me some letters tomorrow I shall think you are all of you rather ill. Thurs. 6 oclock Charles came just now!               I.S.M.
[right-hand side] My every day clothes are every way good and decent, but I ought to have something on other to wear to meeting. I am most ashamed to go sometimes, hardly.
[bottom of page] My clothes are finer than most of the boys at school, but as I have to work, they look dirtier, but I have no best clothes! If I had some coarse to wear every day and some good sun. it would be much better.

Bangor Sat. July 13th 1839

Dear Mother

      I have not recieved a letter from you for a long time, at least it seems so to me; it was sometime last month I believe!. I want very much to know about how your health is now, and everything else that is happening.
  The "Examination" is to be three weeks from yesterday, the second day of August in the year 1839 I dont know whether there will be a school the next day or not. Now. What in the world is to be done? What can I do? I could get along, after a fashion, with the other things, I guess, but, there must be Declamation and Composition. I have been almost in an agony, all day since I heard of it, What shall I do? I have nothing at all to write about, and nothing to write about it!
I have had some notion of running away, and starting for home Wed. or Thursday preceeding the ? !

I dont know anything what to do for a Composition, and it is not a very desirable thing, for me at least, to get up on to the platform, to speak, with the room entirely numbered? with strangers, All looking at I!!!!!!!!!!
There is just a fortnight from to day given to prepare coms' How would it work for me to move home about that time?! O! What is to be done? What? O!
I expect if I could get clear up to the platform, that my knees would tremble so that I could not stand up, without holding on to the post! 
I am very well now, I believe I am a little fatter than I was a month or two ago. We have got through the 6th book in Virgil to the 7th and have just gone back to revise the whole, preparation for examination.
What is to be done about my keeping on to third quarter? Dont Joe want to come too?

Sunday July 11th

   This morning, and in the night some, I had a pain in my bowels, sick at my stomach, or something attended with a diarhea; but I ? got over it pretty much I guess. I did not feel like eating any breakfast, and the folks up and got me a portion of senna and some water gravel? made out of flour, etc. with accustomed kindness. The physic is now operating, I have done being sick to my stomach, and guess that I have got all over it. My health has been  very good indeed all summer, hardly had even a headache at all, been perfectly well and hearty. I had a little minite? mite? of head ache Friday

I have been to meeting this fore noon, on account of my physic. If I got to the school next term, I shall want some new books A Greek reader, perhaps dictionary, and I ought to have a Classical dictionary not the great one that Mr. Hatch had but a small edition which I like better, about as big as my little Latin dictionary. I would also be convenient if I could have one of the new kind of latin grammars,  but I can get along very well without, I guess. I do not want any more books this term. By the way, if I am going to get a really classical education, it is rather a pity that Ann got such an abridgement of Ainsworth's Lexicon, as so poorly bound etc. as that is, I should near cut 2 or 3 most?, and it is not so good neither, though I can get among with it. I did not know until I saw it that there was such an edition I suppose when Ann enquired for Ainsworth: D. they thought they could get rid of one of those, and she did not know but it was the best one. I rather almost think I had better study french next term, if I go, at least when I get through the Algebra.  Had not I?  I have no opinion, myself, that I shall ever go to College. dont know sartin yet. Joe may go if he wants to! or Eliab. James W. has got the Illinois fever, strongly I believe. He says if he had $500, Maine would not see him more than one fortnight.

Monday July 15th
   I have got entirely over my illness; perfectly well, to day only not quite so strong as before, on account of physic and abstinence. Yesterday was the first time that I have been about from the S.S. I want very much to hear about your health. you have not written to me for a long time at least it appears long to me.

I wish you could see how nice our garden looks now a days, the strawberry vines are covered with great white berries, the potatoes are white with blos., the ? almost ready to blos. on it and the beets, carrots are very promising, quite large roots already.  We have not began to hoe potatoes up to the farm yet, but shall this week, they were planted very late, very wet ground.

 I am pretty well off for clothes now if only my clothes all set abominably especially my pants. I dont know whether I had better have a new coat or not. The blue one is much longe than they are now ? page torn and the sleves are very large.  shows it was made for another. I dont know but my dark pants can be altered. I have none ? but a very little this summer, I have not run out any of my clothes much.
 I shall not need any more books this term, and there is not but one, that I must have next term, that I know of now.  that is a Greek read, if one can be got which was published by Little and ___ /young I believe in Boston, last year;  That has not a dictionary it it etc.  If that cannot be obtained (it cant here) I should have to have a great Donnegan's Dict. The other books, Classical Dict. and Andrews and Stoddards Latin Grammar, I could do without, I suppose.

I shall want some time a Greek testament, shall not need it next term I guess but it would be convenient. I want one with Greek and Latin both.  I could ? the Latin now.
I have a good mind to go home just before the examinations it would be so cute?!
You must write to me of home Dear Mother
Your most aff. Son 

                                       I.S. Metcalf
